description: We aren't from the area and stopped in for a drink, I had the cucumber gimlet and my boyfriend had a beer.  My drink was almost undrinkably strong, but worth $9.  Very cute ambiance, dim lighting, really comfortable feel.  I would give 5 stars, but the bartender was way too busy and it took a while to get drinks (and by busy I mean it was a playoff Giants game and he would get distracted by the game and ignore the fact he was serving a packed bar) and there isn't much seating.  Overall very comfortable place to go, will definitely come back if we're in the area again.
author: Liz M.

description:
Big fan.
It's close to school. Close to home. Super close to work. They take cards. They give me chex mix. What more can I ask for?
author: Amanda S.

description:
I love the Owl Tree. I do. I love their well made, classic and classy drinks. I love the feel of the place. I love their own cocktail menu. I love their bar stools. I love their sign. I love the homeless men standing to the side of the windows trying to catch glimpses of the pay-per-view boxing on the tiny HDTV before someone notices. I love the chex-mix (well, not the corn nuts pieces, I hate corn nuts).

Normally such a place would earn 5 stars! But on our most recent visit the bartender was more interested in his iPhone than tending to the customers at the bar. The bar wasn't slammed that night, there were one or two empty stools, but it certainly wasn't slow. We'll be back, I'm sure, hopefully next time the service will be a little better.
author: Emily C.

description: One of my favorite spots to visit yearly while staying in downtown. Friendly staff, good ambiance and generous drinks.
author: Paul R.

description:
Realization is an odd thing. Seconds after sitting down on a couch in the corner, I remembered Owl Tree. Much like Mabel Choate recalling that Jerry Seinfeld stole her marble rye, I remembered. I remembered coming here over a year ago and not liking it. I remembered the way-too-old-for-that-kind-of-foolishness old men cat calling my female friends and stumbling over each other. I remembered the smell. I remembered the bar did me wrong -- and it was doing it again.

My group had reserved the upstairs for a private get together. We were planning on going into that piece 70+ deep. We needed room. I was amongst the first to arrive and inquired about the room. There was no room. Even though the room had been reserved for weeks, the person who put it together forgot to hire a bartender for the night and, yeah. No room. And then we started coming. As more and more of my group piled into the small bar, I began to get irritable. As other, random people piled in because the bar wasn't closed to outside traffic, I got heated. By the time I asked the doorman to help with the crowd and not let anymore folks in (the fire code was a thing of the past) and found out that despite the 'yes' and head nod he gave me, he was still packing the bar with more and more folks, I was nearly homicidal. Deplorable service. There's just no excuse for any of the snafus from the evening. This is what happens when I refuse to listen to my instincts.

So... three stars? Yep. The bartender was smoking hot (sorry; she was/is) and made some mean martinis. She did the best with the hand she was dealt and I need to give props where due. Despite the intolerable crowd, she didn't skimp on the booze and the first drink was as potent as the last. That's professionalism.
author: Johnny T.

description: $3 beer and $4 wells for HH pluuuuus complimentary cheese, salami and crackers to snack on, YAY!!
author: Alexandra V.

description: Not to bad, the atmosphere brought from the bartender wasn't all that great. The people there made it all worthwhile!
author: Patricia R.

description: Get the $10 special, which is a shot of Jameson and a beer.  You get good beer too, not crap bud light.  Very cool ambiance in this place.  The building decor is classy with an owl mosaic and neon sign on the outside.  There is a spot in the corner of the bar you should sit at with your friends.  It is a great place to socialize and have a good ol' time!
author: Devin N.

description:
All the haters are apparently flippin' the fuck out over the redecoration. I frequent the new Owl and not because it's the best bar in town, or because the chandeliers are shinier than the ones at Marina bars, or not because its the cheapest bar, but quite simply, it's directly on the street that is on my way home. It's convenient. I've also never seen placards and velvet ropes. I may drink too much here- but velvet ropes? WTF??

1 star* The Jukebox. They do have one- must be a newer addition. Blues music, Springsteen, The Beach Boys, CCR, Jackson 5. Bring your parents. 

2 stars** Booth dancing and stealth hard wood all around you. 

3 stars*** 2 bathrooms for a small "dive" and snacks that are always proudly displayed: cheese cubes, lil' weiners, and pepperoni. Serve yourself up a heart attack. Bathrooms and food in the same sentence. That's convenient.- Again, Convenience.

4 stars**** The most random "dive" bar crowd in SF. I never thought people in SF could be more random- but enter the new Owl Tree. The new crowd hasn't figured out if they want to stay, or go back to the Marina, or bridge and tunnel it, so I'll park my butt at my neighborhood bar and people watch until they do figure out where to go.
author: Braden B.

description:
While a real owl tree is likely to house a parliament of solitary, nocturnal mouse eating hooters, this Owl Tree houses a grouping of loud, lascivious miscreants. 

On a regular night at Owl Tree it's the ideal spot for a late night cocktail and if you're really desperate for some nibbles and street mice aren't appetizing to you owls, best peruse their cracker and chip table in the corner or ask for a bowl of nuts. I've never ordered any serious cocktails here but the simple concoctions are nice and strong. This once classic Tenderloin tavern was redone a few years ago -- transforming a kitschy, taxidermist booze barn into a classy-er, exposed brick, leather banqueted booze barn. Solid spot to satiate simple tastes, though we will all miss C. Bobby.

Hooty hoo.
author: Jane K.

description:
I really like this place, HOWEVER the bartender tonight is awfull where can I start, I've been at the bar for almost an hour finished my drink in 15 sat it out to make aware I need a refil, no response no attention. He was to busy talking to his buddies, oh and keep in mind I'm sitting at the bar with a visibly empty glass.  Why are you only helping your friends or bro's ???
Sooooo when I finally got the drink he spilled it ?!?! I wish I could get the service he gave other people but didn't. I felt ignored, and over looked.  However I hate playing that card.  The Asian girl, the really pretty Caucasian girl with brown hair that flairs bottles and the red head that speaks German are great!!!! I really like coming here when they are working, and I suggest you do the same. Moving forward ill make sure who's bartending before I come in...awww cute, he gave me pretzels, I guess cause he sees me yelping
POST!!
author: Narada J.

description:
This place was amazing! I actually had never been before and planned a birthday party for my boyfriend here. I just took my chances based on reviews and his recommendation that it was a cool place. When we got there we mentioned we had reserved some tables upstairs and they let us right up. At first it was just our group and then some people from downstairs came up. It was awesome to have designated seats and the bartender upstairs was great. Overall I had a wonderful time, as did all the guests. 

To be honest I was hesitant to even write a review to selfishly keep as many people in the dark about this place as possible :). I would DEFINITELY host another event there.
author: Shiva J.

description: This bar is a great little dive bar. The bartenders are amazing and the conversations with the local patrons are second to none. The first night we came the bartender said this is the place where small town connections happen. Considering we were from the Midwest we didn't expect to meet anyone from our region, we certainly did.  Atmosphere, drink selection and company are all pluses!! Go to this bar and find San Francisco and homegrown contact in the same place.
author: Jesse G.

description:
I have three special little words for you, dear readers: blood orange margarita.

Okay, they might be nice words but "blood orange margarita" does not a review make, no siree. Yet considering I'd already had a couple of deliciously tangy cocktails earlier in the evening at Thermidor, I was certainly in the mood for more. Not too many more, mind, I didn't want to be carried out of the place - thankfully Alex S and I left clear-headed enough to find our way back to the hotel on our own, and considering we had a self-confessed combined awful sense of direction, that was no mean feat. (Let's just have another virtual fist-pump for that moment, mister!)

Back to the cocktail in all its sharp, acidic splendour. I'm always pleasantly surprised when a margarita comes in a tall glass as opposed to a martini one (I'm all kinds of clumsy with those bad boys, and it feels like you're getting better value for your buck anyway) and it was delicious. I'd highly recommend it to anyone like me who prefers a caipirinha to a cosmo and likes a bit of bite in their booze. A big hats off to Noelle who had us all completely enthralled with her cool as a cucumber, sweet as sugar demeanour - I'd be a dreadful bartender, I'd crumble under the pressure of one customer, let alone a floor that had been hired out to a substantial group. She was swift, deft and did not drop her smile once. 

Meanwhile the place is quirky, and you already know how much I dig quirky. Whether it's the retro 80s movies in the background (hello, my perfect bar!) or the jukebox switching from Metallica to Shakira in the blink of an eye, it's charming, it's unusual and it's a bar I'd happily return to in a flash, for the purposes of discussing British vs. American television or anything else. Owls might say whit-woo, but for this place I'd shout a giant woo-hoo!
author: Emma Louise M.

description:
When we hit up the Owl Tree my first thought was.... "ooh dark... I likey", but then after having to shuffle around the bar stools to get situated at the bar I realized something. This place was hot and cramped. It was so hot I was getting claustrophobic. I couldn't even finish my drink and I asked my friend if we could leave.

They did have a lot of interesting looking alcohols that I wanted to inquire about but the female bartender working our side of the bar looked like she wanted to slap me each time I asked a question. I mean come on, you're a bartender isn't it part of your job to be friendly and make small talk? 

I was over this place pretty quick, but I guess it's worth mentioning that my friend really liked her cucumber gimlet.
author: Lori K.

description:
I found myself mesmerized by the deft movements of the bartender. No motion unnecessary, no energy wasted. It was like poetry in motion -- with a delicious ending that leaves you feeling pleasantly buzzed.

The place is dark and relatively small but this lends itself well to cozy little conversations and bumping into folks you want to bump into. 

I only wish I'd seen some owls, as that would have completed the experience. I also want to know how three cocktails got me so hammered. Seriously, what are you putting in your drinks? Next time, I will know better and just get one. One!
author: Olivia L.

description:
Great place to go after work, especially if you are on a budget! Well the drinks are kind of spending, but it is surprising how one can fill up on the free cheese, meats, crackers, and chex mix they offer! 

I have a huge thing for seating (specifically booths) and this place had really comfortable seating! It very dark inside and cozy, but also loud at the same time.. loved the vibe! 

The Blackberry Martini was my favorite, I tried the one with the cucumber as well, which was refreshing, but then switched back to the Blackberry drink for the rest of the night.
author: Rona Y.

description: Very Mad Men. It's like the scene of some old Hollywood movie here -- all that's missing (thankfully) are the huge clouds of smoke. Everything about Owl Tree feels very dark and masculine, including the flocks of old white businessmen. Not bad for an intimate group of friends looking to escape the usual crowds in Marina/Mission, but don't expect a wild night out.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I think this place used to be a cool dive, and now it is this somewhat schizophrenic place in an equally schizophrenic area of town. It has this sort of swanky interior to match how much they charge for mixed drinks, and they put out a cute spread of cheese and cold cuts for happy hour. It's small and cozy, and on the weekends they open an equally small second floor.

The thing that I can't get over here is the music. This listing says "juke box" but I haven't noticed it. And jukeboxes aren't a great idea if you end up listening to The Beastie Boys, Will Smith, The Bee-Gees, The Cure, Outkast, Frank Sinatra, and Def Leppard. In that order. 

I'm not kidding. I actually enjoyed most of the songs they played at one point in my life, but altogether it was so weird and distracting that it felt like I was being forced to sit  in the middle of a room while every man I'd ever been with paraded around in front of me in his underwear.
author: stephanie l.

description:
When looking for a drink, a giant owl mosaic appeared in front of my eyes.. obviously hypnotized I was drawn inside where the object of my desire (pre-dinner alcoholic beverages) awaited. 
People were chill, drinks were fine and served as expected. Not divey, and prices reflected that. There were quite a few people in there either speaking a different language or with a euro accent, which was kind of interesting - I don't know if that's a regular thing or if it was just a party that night. I can't say this would be my usual spot but like yelp says, three stars = A-OK.
author: Jeanie C.

description: Found this place by pure luck... While walking on Post st. Dark and Cozy... Lovely wooden old school bar.. Full bar... Downside for me being that I am a Beer fan is the limited beer selection. Nice little laid back place. Great place to catch a basketball game if you just want to have a drink and enjoy.
author: Diego V.

description:
Fun place! Came here on a Saturday night with a friend and was pleased with the cocktails menu -- mango mojito? Two of my favorite things! Yum. Love that there is lounge-style seating even though it is a small bar. Was full without being crowded.

I don't know if I'd recommend it for a large group, but definitely a fun place to grab a drink with a friend or perhaps for happy hour, which I'll have to try next.
author: Richa A.

description:
Does Owl Tree really deserve a classification as a dive bar?  I don't think so, but I guess there isn't a category for "Hilariously confused bar."

I walked in here with my partner while trying to kill an hour and a half before dinner up the street (we aren't very good at gauging how long it takes for us to walk places).

At first I was incredibly skeptical -- the place is small enough that you need a shoehorn to get into, a techno remix of Sinnerman was blasting,  and there was a hefty dash of drunk after-work types.

After picking up the menu I was quite happily suprised $7-9 cocktails, including a $9 Hendrick's gimlet, a solid Manhattan, and four actual, real, beer drinker's beers on tap.  Yes, please!

Service was fantastic, too.  A very personable bartender that checked up with us every ten minutes despite the full bar, and a server that replaced our Chex mix bowl within a minute of us snatching the last cheese puff.

It's got a comfy interior that reminds me of a DC steakhouse.  The music and crowd signal something trendier, but the drinks and the bartenders tell me that I'm in a dive bar.  Stop playing with my mind, cruel owners!  This is a great regular after-work hangout, don't dress it up like it's a date bar!

The Owl Tree is like the first person you had a crush on.  You don't know what's really going on, you feel confused and a little bit nauseous, but you want more.
author: Bill H.

description:
Yawn....

Owl Tree, you're nothing special.  Sure you may be super hot (literally) but I can't base a relationship on heat factor.  You're dark and mysterious (decor) but that's about it.  You took me upstairs but your place was a bit cramped and blah, I had to get out immediately.

It's just not going to work out Owl Tree!  

PS. Rick and George please stop expanding and making over-priced lackluster bars in the city.  You're killing me!  Poor Brunos, an SF institution turned into some safe-marina bar in the mission.
author: Kristin Marie S.

description: Cute, warm  little bar on a corner. Has a very traditional old fashioned feel.  Not a very good place for a great glass of wine. But if you are more like my husband who likes cocktails without any frills it's perfect, because this is not where you will find a talented mixologist. Cute, homey Christmas Decor (in Dec)
author: J C.

description: Who thought the tenderloin was bad? This place is great! We came from out of town and wanted to watch the hockey game and they put it on right away.  We went to 4 other bars in the area to get a specific drink and no one could provide it for us...well....another story for another time.  If you go, pray Gabi is working because she's the best!
author: Mark S.

description:
Call first-Bobby seems to take a lot of time off!  

ZAZZ!  I love this place!  It is always a toss-up if Bobby is crabby or not each time one goes. :)    Bobby is pure class, though.  I love his freshly laundered white shirts and he knows how to make a drink.  Spy on your friends with his web cam-or have them spy on you! :)

Makes me want to go tonight-darn he is only open Weds-Sat 5pm on--razz!   :(   I am thirsty!
Note; Bobby passed away late in 2006.  I heard his son was going to reopen it, but I don't know if that happened! 
2008-i have heard it has reopened.
author: BRUCE S.

description:
I've been here a few times now, and there seem to be some regular truisms at play when it comes to Owl Tree: they know their way around a cocktail, and if you drop in when they have one bartender working, chances are said barkeep will be conducting a veritable clinic on how to cut up a room...I'll say this: I've seen this place super packed on more than one occasion, and in a city that appreciates a well crafted cocktail, they still seem to turn out concoctions without a major wait. 

If you haven't gathered by now, the Owl Tree is a rather diminutive space with some intentionally rough edges, but I think that it says something that a bar that can feel this small and crowded also feels somewhat group friendly. All I know is that it's probably not a terrible idea that you know your friends well or enjoy their company, as you'll likely find yourself in close quarters. I'm sure I'll find myself, brew in hand, in the neighborhood again one of these days, and that means one thing, really: good times ahead.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Second trip to the Owl Tree, and I think it's just not my kind of place. The bar is deep and narrow -- and unless you grab some coveted bar stools at the bar or one of the little seating areas on the left, you're a bit out of luck because standing (or trying to navigate anywhere) in a narrow bar that's crowded is no fun.

Had a vodka and soda that was decidedly weak. And two of the three bartenders just seemed pretty irritated that they were so slammed -- we were a giant group but in our defense, had called weeks ahead to let them know.

The music was super-eclectic (from No Doubt to Rump Shaker) and was one of my favorite things about the venue... certainly keeps you on your toes!
author: Christina G.

description:
What a cool spot.

Dive downstairs and loungy upstairs.

You can reserve seating upstairs and the bartender up there makes the drinks STRONG! The beer selection is lacking but you should be getting Hard A here anyway.

Check it out!
author: Jessica L.

description:
Walking down Powell and I'm stopped because the company knows the hot chic walking towards us.  Hello!  I'm introduced to Noelle...nice to meet you!  She tells us that she's heading to work at Owl Tree...hmmm...never heard of it.  Now I don't know why I automatically assumed it was a dive bar but I remember thinking it'd be cool if I walked in one day.

Cut about six months later and since a quick late dinner was being consumed nearby we might as well check it out...walked in and said hello to Nicole...???...um, no! my name is Noelle...CRAP!!! complete embarrassment...I'm sure she wasn't too pleased at being called by another name either...TOTAL FAILURE!!! =(

But I appreciate that she still put on a smile (slightly awkwardly, understandably) and didn't allow my moment of being a complete moron hinder her heavy hand.  Graciously my company picked up the rest of the drinks which was great for me more since it meant I didn't have to face the bartender again for the rest of the night.

The Owl Tree is a chic and mysterious type of lounge lit by soft lighting and candlelight.  The bartenders know what they're doing and (insert any compliment that could possibly not make me an idiot for my mishap).

hahaha ok...enough.  Though seriously, I'm sort of wanting to throw a get-together in their upstairs lounge
...where I will definitely remember NOELLE!!! =)
...I apologize btw
author: Ninja H.

description:
Hmm forgot to write a review of this place. My girlfriend and I actually visited this place a few months ago. We both had a recollection of this place being a dive but since our first bar was closed that night we decided to walk over and give this place a shot. 

So I'm a sucker for that old school swingers loungy feel and the Owl Tree when I walked it had that a bit. bunch of couches and chairs along the wall and a long bar with people posted. We scored spots at the bar and my gf and were able to order drinks to our hearts content.

What I really liked was it had a good energy. It was just us two but the place had a lively vibe to it and it just brought our mood up with it. Definitely will probably swing by here again on a random night like we did before.
author: Hyung L.

description: This place would be huge if it were in Sacramento. Since it's in the City it's just another decent dive bar. I'm from Sacramento and it was close to my hotel, so I dug it very much. We missed happy hour but drinks were reasonably priced and they have a passable selection of whiskey and a few good beers on tap. The mural and all the owl shwag inside play nicely with the modern decor and the low lights make everyone 28% cooler. Upstairs was closed, but I suspect it's even cooler up there: maybe some live owls or cheap massages. I'll go back to find out. When we were there they were playing Beverly Hills Cop on the TV which is awesome.
author: Logan J.

description:
The Owl Tree is the kind of place where you take a casual first date because you're pretty sure that other someone is pretty laid back and not the type of person who tries too hard. Yeah yeah yeah, I know that it's SF standard to throw down some metro peacocking and striped shirts on a first date....but if you met said person at say, a dive bar in The Tenderloin (truth), let's not fool anybody.

But seriously though, you can reveal a lot about a person's character when you bring them to a place like this. It's this casual zone between "kinda divey" and "nice enough." The decor is an accessible level of eccentric. The draft selection, though small, is thoughtful. They have Bulleit. (Actually, I got in the habit of mentioning who has that because I just relocated from Boston and unicorns are more common than Bulleit...but, here, it seems to be everywhere). The prices are decent. The lighting (or lack thereof) is flattering. (I look my "hottest" in dive bars...the thirtysomething's best defense). The bathrooms are clean. (Did I ever tell you about how much I missed toilet seat covers when I was living on the East Coast? It's so nice to see those everywhere again.) And the playlist is awesomely terrible. If your possibly special someone finds no unironic humor or appreciation to Wang Chung's "Everybody Have Fun Tonight, " then send that asshole packing. Or, at least I would because I shamelessly and unironically (forgive me, I live amongst the hipsters in Temescal these days) love that song. 

Four solid stars.
author: Zulu Q.

description: Nice cool bar, great bartender and the prices are reasonable. Good music, clean bathroom, friendly bartender is why this deserves a great rating. If you have a small group of 8 or less this is a cool place to hang out.
author: Krishna Y.

description:
This place has some sick drinks. They are unique but not fru-fru, and they are certainly strong!! I loved the super chill atmosphere and free  snacks. I came here for Yelp Drinks, but I will certainly be back for happy hour.  The spot is super cute with low tables for optimal chit chat and libation enjoyment.

I recommend checking out this if you are down around TL or Union Square.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
I came here with 9 other people on a Friday night around 10pm and we just lounged around upstairs. I absolutely loved the decoration and atmosphere of the bar. Like other people said, it's like a dive bar. It has very nice furnishing and super comfy leather ottomans.

The upstairs bar sucks because it's tiny and does have a lot of alcohol. We should have gone downstairs for our drinks but we were too lazy. You can also rent out the upstairs for parties and events. Overall the drinks weren't that expensive. A shot of patron was only $8. Another note about the upstairs area, there really wasn't any service available. There was no menu as in some of the pictures and there was definitely no snacks or food. Also, they don't give you water, you have to buy their bottles of water. I think it's $3 for a bottle.

The people there were really nice and also very hip. I definitely want to go back again and try the downstairs area.
author: Lucy D.

description: Great little bar int the union square, love the local scene here.  very friendly bartenders strong drinks and great door man.  if you want to get away from the union square club scene this is the place to go
author: Shirley W.

description:
Owl Tree! What a cute name for a bar! 

My roommate and I used to go here all the time when we live just down the block. There's always people chilling just outside of the bar, and they're usually really friendly. We've gotten stopped and offered drinks many times just by walking pass it (but only taken up offers a few times when they seem like really nice decent people, and they were). People who go here are really friendly, it's really easy to chat up anyone.

They got free otsumami, and if you run out, they'll just keep filling it up!

Really good mojitos. The passion fruit mango mojito is so sweet and delicious!

There's an upstairs, but it's usually closed until it gets too crowded downstairs. It's a lounge atmosphere upstairs, good for groups, small bar, really easy to talk to everyone/people watch through those huge windows.

I'll have to go early and check out their happy hour!
author: Erica L.

description:
AWESOME SPOT. very comfy and loungy. They don't have food, but the lay out cheese, crackers and salami for you on a side table, and offer pub mix (yum!)

The service is outstanding, the drinks pretty good. I had a pomegranate martini, and although I don't care for martinis, this one was damn good. Totally hit the spot.

I'd definitely go back to this spot!
author: Chi N.

description: Cute place -- casual and swank at the same time.  The ambiance is great too --- a step above a dive bar, and they have Blue Moon, always a plus.  A great place to grab happy hour with friends.
author: Mel G.

description: Comfy little saloon type place with nice bartenders and decent cocktails. Nice snacks lying around -- of course they're there to get you thirsty and to drink more, but hey, they are damn tasty. Only complaint, and a big one at that, is that the price for cocktails is a bit high. At roughly $9, they are only a dollar or two away from Rye drinks, and you can't compare these drinks to what they have at Rye, especially considering it's not too far away. I'd come back here if I wanted to mix it up during a night out, but I'm not aching to return.
author: Josh K.

description:
How do I choose what my first review of 2010 should be? Easy, write about where I was when I brought in the New Year.

It was 30 minutes till midnight, and I alongside with my fellow orphans on a budget are wandering aimlessly through the Mission on a mission.  Must find a place for a drink...fast.  Everywhere we turned was either at capacity or $45 at the door.  Think fast...think fast...think fast.  Take a cab and head downtown.

I recall in my memory of past drunken evenings of a fun dive bar situated on Post.  Music is ok, drinks are good, and bartenders are fast.  We escape our cab and run to the door (20 minutes till midnight), and $10 cover! Score! We gladly pay, proceed on through, squeeze our way upstairs with one thing on our minds...get to the bar...we are thirsty!  First cran/vodka of the night down my throat and warming up my tummy (10 minutes till midnight).  I look around, it's getting thick in here. I need another drink, but bartender has quite a few people ahead of me.  Where is our friend Matt? There's 5 minutes left till countdown? We succumb to our fate (champagne-less counting down from 20 now), and accept our next drink will come at the start of 2010.  

"Ten, nine, eight,..."

Matt appears...are those 6 champagne glasses in his hands?

"Seven, six,...."

Grab one, and pass one. Grab one, and pass one.

"Five, four, three, two, one"!

A toast in the air, I scream Happy New Year, I coat my throat with that sweet champagne, smiles on our faces. We find seats by the window, open up the curtains, and people watch as we celebrate the night away.  What a way to bring in 2010.

This is dedicated to Matt, who saved the day. 2010 will now be officially termed "Year of The Matt" amongst us.
author: Maybelline C.

description: Clean environment, ok drinks, and a quiet crowd. If the crowd was a little more extroverted, might be an ok place to hang out? About a 50 / 50 chance you will have a good time. Tempted to visit Owl Tree again, though this visit was somewhat disappointing. What often makes a good bar in SF, not the decor or location, it is the people.
author: Henry J.

description:
We wanted to grab a quick beer near our hotel and was recommended The Owl Tree. Slipping into this bar, it feels very small at first and has a small door guarded by a large man. I was hesitant at first and even though I do not look underage, he carded me. He was polite about it, but it was briefly offputting. 

My colleagues were already there and I slid in next to them. It felt a little dark and a little cramped. I had a New Belgium Fat Tire which is the same sort of beer I could've bought on the street, but this beer was served in a frozen glass. 

It was small, dark and crowded but not too bad - if that's your thing.
author: Devon A.

description:
Not good for big groups unless you book the upstairs room. We had a group of ~15 & had to wedge our way everywhere in this small bar. Thankfully the seats/couches are comfy. 

There was only 1 bartender on a Sat night - WHAT?? so service was slower than I'd have liked & it was packed. The decor takes up much of the space - tables, couches, bar stools - so there's little room to mingle. 

Good thing they accept credit cards & not overly priced.
author: Marissa H.

description:
The Owl Tree is a classic SF dive bar.  Or should I say, "was" a classic dive bar. 

I came here saturday night for a few beers and was surprised when I entered. Someone has completely renovated this bar. It has a new dark wooden interior, a new bar, two leather booths, and a back lounge area. Plus a private room upstairs. This was once a San Francisco dive bar where we drank jack and cokes and smoked marlboro reds.  There were old business cards tacked up behind the bar, and people casually met here for cocktails, conversation, and to play around with the old jukebox. 

Now this place is like Fabio meets Casey Kasem. There were two pumped up italian dudes wearing black t-shirts two sizes too small behind the bar. This attracts some gushing women cliental. Overall it was nice to see that the bar was revamped. 

But minus two stars for the worst bar mix I have ever heard. They mixed eighties hair metal with hip hop from the early nineties like Warren G's track "Regulate, (not that bad), but inexplicitly went from playing this track, to Warrant's "Cherry Pie," and then played "Ice, Ice, Baby," by Vanilla Ice. Come on by to hear Owl Tree's Wack Mix Vol. 1.

Also, if you're a guy, make sure you've got that Marina collar, starched, popped, and in ready formation.
author: Georgio N.

description:
A cool little place to chill and have a drink. Came here during Yelp Drinks! 2011 with my roommate. 

We sipped on a couple of the Fresh Blackberry Martinis. And they were rather tasty. 

It's somewhere nice to hang out if you just need to chill.
author: Lauren H.

description: Good corner bar. Much nicer on the inside than one would think from looking at the outside.  $4 drink happy hour 4 pm - 7 pm; some free cheese and crackers at the end of the bar.
author: Jefferson L.

description: I love this place. The $3 happy hour drafts (good ones, too, not just Bud Lites) and free cheese and crackers mitigated some of the horror of a 4-week stay in the Tenderloin.
author: Tess H.

description:
I love this place, totally my neighbor bar! The ambiance is really fun with SF based movies on the TV's only, great comfy chairs, and you can totally imagine someone in the 80's snorting coke off the tables!

They have a great drink collection, although some of the bartenders are better then others, I would definitely recommend the cucumber gin martini.
author: Megan R.

description:
**This review is for the Happy Hour only

Cheap and delicious. $3 drafts and $4 wells until 7p plus FREE cheese and salami. Yum. The cute blond bartender with the long hair is great. She has great bar backs backing her up too. I always have a great time here!
author: Alice J.

description:
Met up with some friends here last night (Saturday) and I have to say whoever the bartender and bar back are - you're both amazing!  Best service I've had in a bar in a while.
The place is packed, people are throwing crazy orders at him, I returned three times with my card only to say, "close it out" each time (I really thought each round was the last) and these guys are knocking orders out, ringing people up, keeping the whole place clean, bringing water to our table.  I'm really impressed guys, good job!
author: Corey V.

description: This is my after work watering hole. It's right down the street from my office. The drinks are reasonable, free bar snacks and the bartenders are always nice. I love coming here.
author: Manny C.

description: My favorite SF bar.  It's my go-to spot for happy hour because of the location, friendliness, atmosphere, and free food.  Yes, free food.  They have help-yourself salami, crackers, cheese, and Chex mix.  It does get crowded at times, but usually you can find a spot at the bar or in a booth.
author: Bud L.

description:
Sleek, winsome owl decor wraps itself around the exterior of this particular bar. Inside, the theme winds down a little bit, as two televisions flicker with sports. The bartenders are pretty generically robotic, as they plunk away on their computerized cash registers, taking orders with little animation. 

What's on tap? Nothing special. The obligatory domestic beers pop up more than once. They have one or two craft beers in bottles, which should placate artisan beer snobs. 

But the music is the real tragedy. I can only imagine that, with the bizarre transitions in tempo, someone brought their ipod shuffle into the bar, plugged in an audio cable to some speakers, then let the worst mix of songs bounce off the walls of the place. The party that I came with heard Rick Springfield's "Jesse's Girl" three times in an hour. There was also flamenco music wafting through the air before it gave way to "Ooops, I Did it Again" by Brittany Spears. The volume was bumped up much too loud for casual conversation, so patrons have to vehemently bark over one another like rabid canines. 

And why did they start playing Reese Witherspoon's "Just Like Heaven" on the two televisions after they had been showing UFC for an hour? The whole place had little to no consistency in its identity, temperament, clientele. 

Bleh.
author: Rob P.

description: Cool little spot. Got the greyhound, which was pulpy like I like. Tough to get a drink if there are more than a dozen people here.
author: Khalid N.

description: Cute little bar to grab a beer after dinner or a show, but stick to beer or wine, as the cocktails are not very good, yet still as pricey as anywhere else.
author: Brett B.

description: Great little bar with good drinks, comfy atmosphere and just an all around cozy place to sip some cocktails. Nice place to grab a drink before dinner at Sakana (awesome sushi next door).
author: Ennis O.

description:
Just a few blocks away from the craziness that is Union Square and you'll find the Owl Tree.  Not only Owl lovers adore the owl-focused decor- but everyone will love the classic decor in this great bar!  Once seated in one of the comfy booths downstairs or the cool lounges upstairs - you're served with mixed nuts to help soak up the delicious cocktail you're about to imbibe!

My favorite is the Hendrick's Cucumber Gimlet - carefully muddled and served up in a martini glass ready for my consumption!  Oh. The. Joy!

They have a nice little happy hour too - with a little spread of meats and cheeses to graze on.  

Only complaint (if you can call it that) is that their music selection is quite random - but that makes it even more endearing to me....They'll play anything from INXS to Guns N Roses to Britney Spears - all in that order too!  It's kinda weird but fun when you're really just there to chat with friends over a well crafted cocktail!
author: Heather L.

description: Very cute dive from the outside, nicely remodeled upstairs. Conveniently located, easy to find, not too overly crowded, but plenty of people. Love the mosaic of the owl on the front (makes it easy to recognize- and artistic at the same time!) Drinks were fine, bartender was cool, bouncer friendly. Well done.
author: Naomi K.

description: A cool kinda dive bar near Union Square with good vibe albeit it is a small place.  I would return for happy hour or late night.
author: Chris C.

description: Little dive bar downtown. Good place to grab a drink.
author: Jay W.

description: One of many great bars in this area, the Owl Tree has a variety of drinks and music to please everyone
author: Mike P.

description:
Hung out here on a Friday night.  We were with a pretty big group of out-of-towners who were in SF for a wedding.  First impression of the Owl Tree was that it's quite random.  The movie "The Rock" (with Sean Connery and Nicholas Cage) was playing on both flat screens above the bar, the music was an eclectic gamish of upbeat tunes from the 80s to the present (in no particular order), and its dark decor aptly camouflaged its dive-bar roots.  Crowd was laid back, which was good because it was really cramped.  Lord knows you want laid-back people around when you have to practically squeeze your naughty bits up against random strangers just to get to the bar.

Overall, not bad, but I prefer places that aren't quite so claustrophobic.
author: Christine G.

description:
I miss your chex mix
I miss your stiff drinks
I miss your dark owls
I miss your doggie

However I know someday we will be reunited.
author: A. E.

description: I've been coming here since before the renovation.  They did a fantastic job of upgrading while paying homage to the old guy's owl collection.  Take a look at the case at the end of the bar, at the stairs.  Before the renovation, the whole place was full of all those owl knick-knacks.
author: Byron D.

description:
Good crowd.  Nice bartenders who make great drinks.  

My only issue with the place is that I was there when someone stole someone's purse.  So becareful! Watch your purse!

That's the only reason I didn't give it a 4-star rating.
author: Stacy S.

description: Great bar to hang out at!! Enjoy it each time I come!! Small, quaint, friendly!! Good place to start or end your night.
author: Wendy K.

description: Passed through for a quick drink.  Cocktails feel on the pricey side since they were not very strong.  I'd pass this place and go to Olive if you're looking for drinks with a kick!
author: Christopher L.

description:
Nice place to go to grab a drink and still be able to chit chat. Looks ugly on the outside but real nice inside. Looks like some deer hunters's hidden den and i'm waiting for Mr. Hugh himself walk out with a cigar and his robe to welcome me. 

I like their Blood Orange Margarita! Yay tequila! Also has chex mix, which i like. The bartenders are pretty friendly, most of the time it's not jammed pack so I always get a seat. Last time I went, they served cheese & crackers. The music is real random, one minute it's 80's and next it's rhianna, maybe an ipod on shuffle.

this place is clean, nice, small, cozy and close by home.

P.S. owl if your reading, i'd come here everyday, if you served food. LOL
author: Tam T.

description: Awesome little spot, great drinks.  Another huge plus..they have free cheese and crackers! Only drawback is it's a little small
author: Ryan H.

description: First time visiting San Fran. We were staying at the hotel down the street and stumbled into this watering hole. We loved it!! The decor was similar to that if a yacht and a lounge had a baby= Owl Tree. Prices were reasonable and the service was great. There is definitely a nice mix of locals and visitors from nearby hotels. Once we found this spot...we went back a few times before our trip was over. (Being from New Orleans...We like an eclectic feel) We are still talking about the owl tree!
author: Marcie D.

description:
I have a pretty random review to write...

I was at the Owl Tree a week and a half ago for a private party. They have a great room upstairs and were very accommodating to my friend that had organized the whole party. Looonnnngggg story short, someone stole my purse. It was a private party so most likely it was someone I know. Needless to say, I was not in the best of moods. 

I borrowed a friend's phone and tried calling my bank and my phone. I was standing out front and visibly upset and Anthony, the bouncer/security gave me his stool to sit on and basically just had some nice comforting words. I stayed until the end of the night, just incase it had fallen somewhere and we could find it. Anthony came up and checked in to see if we'd found it and then told me he'd check out the security tapes. 

I followed up the next day and everyone I talked to at the bar was aware of the situation. When things like this have happened before, I feel like I've had to to explain my situation over and over, but everyone knew who I was. I went in to look at the tape and it turned out there it was no help, but while I was waiting to look, I talked to a lot of great people, enjoyed the snacks they had put out and decided that in spite of my purse being stolen there, I really liked this place. I'd definitely go back there. 

Like I said...random
author: Jaime S.

description: My cousin Megs & I met up with some friends we haven't seen in a long time here at The Owl Tree. It's your typical hole-in-the-wall dive bar, really chill & low key. We got there a little bit early on a Sunday, so there were a few people by the bar. The bartender was really nice and accommodating because my Iphone was about to die so he let me charge my phone with him. The crowd varied from tourists, hipsters & just-moved-in from out of town. My friends ordered some fruity martinis and I had a blood orange margarita which was really good. It's definitely a great place to go to if you want to just chill with your friends or just unwind after a day of strolling in the city.
author: Niki P.

description:
Before C. Bobby died:

[Setting: Saturday night downtown. A not-too-dimly lit bar with either shag carpeting or else an overall feel that makes the average observer think he's standing on shag carpeting; lots of low, wooden tables and chairs; about 17,000 representations of owls.] 

Patron: Hey, how you doin? 
Barkeep: What'll it be?
Patron: My name's [redacted]. What's yours?
Barkeep: C. Bobby.
Patron: Great! What's the C. stand for? 
Barkeep: What do you think it stands for? C.! Now what the hell do you want? 

After C. Bobby died: 

Yelp reviewer: "Really good mojitos. The passion fruit mango mojito is so sweet and delicious!" 


Sigh. I had my arm suddenly around a random Irish woman's waist one winter night at the Owl Tree years and years ago. It was raining and glorious, and my friend had parallel-parked his car .4 blocks away, on a hill, in two turns and with no more than two (2) inches to spare on either end. We took pictures of the interstitial wonder and emailed them back and forth to each other. The Owl Tree, even at that late Saturday night hour, was well-lit because they had no secrets, and she had such red hair. We'd run into a guy we went to college with (college in MA, mind you), and then had more drinks with C. Bobby and that Irish girl. Oh strange lassie, I'd've  had no idea what to do with you that night, but I still wish I'd gone home with you.
author: T U.

description:
Great chill place for drinks downtown.

Pros-
- Chill Atmosphere
- Seating
- Great location

Cons-
Limited draft selection
Expensive

Really enjoyed this place, I'll be back.
author: Brett M.

description: Somebody sucked the soul out of this place with a straw. Before the remodel it was a kitschy jewel. Now it's just another yup-hole. The only things that save it from 1-star oblivion are the free snacks and the $10 Jameson-and-a-beer special.
author: Stuart M.

description:
I love this place. Great atmosphere. Chill but not chilled out. Upstairs is my fav spot in the city. 
Bartenders are awesome and door guy is awesome !
Can not recommend this place enough
author: Spanky M.

description:
I love this place! Although small, the ambiance is great, and drinks are moderately priced. It's got a great location, and is a very simple way to start or end your evening. I've spent anywhere from ten minutes to 3 hours in this bar, and always felt very at ease. 

If you scan down the list of reviews, you will find Susan M. She reviewed this bar very negatively after her experience Saturday night. She claimed "the bouncers suck", that they "called last call at 1:15am", and they wouldn't let her "finish her drink". I had the opportunity to talk to the particular bouncer she spoke of last night, who in fact (after finding out about her ridiculous Yelp review) is pressing charges against SUSAN M. for PUNCHING HIM IN THE FACE after he told her the upstairs was closed and she could finish her drink downstairs in the remaining 20 minutes that the bar was open. She refused to go downstairs MULTIPLE times and only AFTER she punched him TWICE in the face did he grab her and call the police. Anyway, I found Susan M's perception of this incident WILDLY AMUSING and also completely MISCONCEIVED.

The bouncers do NOT suck, the bartenders are nice, and the place is always comfortable and relaxed. Watch out for totally insane women though, apparently they sit upstairs and have no concept of time while they are wildly punching strangers.
author: Margaret H.

description:
I'm pretty sure I'm banned for life from the Owl Tree...or at least only allowed to order a diet soda.

I used to frequent this little hole in the wall when I worked in Union Square. It's dark, on a random corner where you won't run into anyone you don't want to run into, the bartenders are chill and drinks are decently priced. I wouldn't recommend it for late night but right after work the crowd is happy and friendly. I'm a fan of the retro 70's touch and the small booths near the window. What can I say, I like to people watch.

Unfortunately my girlfriends and I took happy hour way past the legal limit a few months ago and I haven't been back since. Not because I didn't have a blast, but because all three of us have no recollection of leaving the Tree...I left my ATM card there and woke up in the morning, topless, face down on my bed, all the lights on, my Brita water pitcher on my night stand and my stereo turned on full blast to a mariachi station. Guess that means I had a good time...party on Owl Tree!! Maybe I'll wear a disguise and sneak back one day.
author: Lynsey C.

description: I'm moving out of the hood this weekend and I find this place!?  What a jip.  Great vibe, great drinks, free snacks!  What else could you want?
author: Ashley W.

description:
I once heard a swing tune emanating from Owl Tree, which led me to take a peek.  I love this place.  They play a good variety of music ranging from Pretty Woman to Fugees, etc.  Their flat screens show a variety of movies filmed in and around San Francisco.

This place is comfortably swanky.  Low, dark ceilings, a long bar, tables-chairs along the wall, a few dim chandeliers for a bit of class. 

The people and staff are friendly.  Ask for the 'Wojtek' (pronounced Voy-Tek) cocktail it was created by a bartender of the same name.
author: Cathy K.

description:
It's simple math:

1 Star for being the only bar in a 5 block radius from our hotel that was playing the Kansas game (even though they lost...I won't hold that against them)

+

1 Star for a $1 off my beer during happy hour, and the bartender notifying me that there was 1 minute left to order another

+ 

1 Star for free Cheez-it's party mix to satisfy my hunger pains before dinner

+ 

1 Star for the sultry ambiance and cool atmosphere that made me want to hang out there all night

=

4 Stars
author: Lacey M.

description:
This was one of our favorites 3-5 years back- I guess they had an ownership change because this was not at all the way I remembered when I returned on Friday night...

Definitely not the vibe of the old Owl Tree; but still offers up a relaxed atmosphere, comfy booths, and great drinks.  Fresh squeezed greyhound is worth the trip alone.
author: Gabrielle J.

description: Fun Environment. Blocks away from my work, so that's a plus especially for Happy Hour. I loved the little stash of cold cuts and cheeses in the back of the bar for happy hour, special treat. Upstairs is a nice little hideaway with it's own private bar and more seating area. But watch out, if it's crowded up there for an event, it gets hot. The bar as a whole is a limited seating and standing room but fun place to hang out after a busy day working in the Union.
author: Mariam Z.

description:
For my four-hundredth review, I thought I share a secret to you all,

Tila Tequila works here and she makes an incredible drink.

Sex in my pants!
author: Stanley K.

description:
I was just throwing down on a grillmin cheese and tomato soup when i was asked if i had gone downstairs to check the mail.

I get this rush of tingly glee when i check the mail. Not because i cant wait to pay bills, or see if i got a free sample of Melon Mango Chocolate GAIN.....but for a reason all the better.

I secretly wish for some underground evil organization to send me an invitation to join them.

Kinda like.....

"Dear Mr _________

It is at this time that Global Diabolical Shitstorm Inc, would like to offer you a mid level position in our family for a negotiable salary based on your experiences.

We feel your radioactive plate in your leg and your Beard of Loki have alot to offer our organization and believe that if you join our family, there is a very bleak and dark future for justice.

If you chose to accept, all accomodations, marketing (your persona logo and branding, as well as mysterious backstory) and evil training will be provided, after an in depth personality scan with our space age cerebral scanners. In addition to an additional undisclosed bonus power we will provide.

We have also included a CD-R of some possible theme music for you that will be played whenever you enter an esablishment. Feel free to supply your own if these arent fitting for you.

You will be expected to provide an apprentice (a ward, if you will) if you choose, and eventually earning your own nemesis.

There is alot of room to grow at GDS, and you wont have to worry about a glass ceiling. Because it isnt glass, its my mental forcefield, and youll never be strong enough to break it.

We look forward to hearing from you, and eventually working with you.

Signed,

_____________

Yes...thats what i wait for. 

And i also know this...The Owl Tree would be MY lair. Why? Aside from the sweet jukebox, the untouched 70's decor will be an amazing front for the massive panels of devices and blinking lights that beep and boop.

Also, my sidekick is going to be a black owl with red eyes named Professor Cheevers that has the ability to read minds and demolecularize people into Gardeto's Snack mix. 

Now if youll excuse me, i have some mail to check.
author: Mick F.

description: Unfortunately they don't have the owls decor anymore but the drinks are stiff.
author: Rosie M.

description:
I really wanted to hate the Owl Tree. I mean the original had so much character, and I kind of enjoyed being the poser hipster sort trying to be part of a really cool dive scene (calling it a scene just proves why I am a poser, at least in these circumstances).

Anyway, the place closed after Bobby passed away, sometime went by and then a few months ago the guys who own Harry's (and now Bruno's) took over the joint. If you know how Bruno's used to be and have been there in the last year or so, you can see why I was ready to not like this place (in short, they sort of sucked the soul out Bruno's but it's more packed than ever, go figure).

So it was with some apprehension that I finally paid a visit to the reborn establishment. The interior has been cleaned up, but they have kept the general sensibility of the space intact, sadly minus all the great owl memorabilia that made The Owl Tree so legendary in the first place; there is a nice glass-encased memorial which does honor the history, so I'll give them some props.

No jukebox, a huge disappointment, and see my previous review for why that is so.

They are building out the upstairs, so that's intriguing, a plus for renovation without too much loss of integrity.

Finally, the drinks. I suppose they are priced around what they should be for the neighborhood, cocktails ranging between $8-10. It's not for the old timers, that's for sure (maybe they could offer a local discount?). I went with their Gin & Tonic, served with Junipero and with an individual bottle of Fever Tree Tonic, so that you could mix to your own perfection. Yeah, I was kind of impressed.

So where does that leave us? Now that I've lived in SF for over 10 years, I guess I'm starting to develop a sense of time and character. Sure, it was sad to see the original bar close. But you know what, time goes on, and while this isn't a Phoenix rising, it still is an Owl.
author: Nish N.

description:
A moment of silence for the Owl Tree...

It limped along for about 6 months after Bartender/Owner Bobby's death but, it appears that it too has now died.

I laughed here, I cried here, got my hair caught on fire here, and fended off many offers of cocaine here.

Cheers to what was!

(I wonder what's gonna happen to all of that kooky owl paraphernalia?)
author: R M.

description: I have been here in a while but at some point it as my fav. place. Polish bartender is friendly or maybe that is only because I am Polish myself. Anyway, great snacks like cheese and mini hot dogs.
author: Magda G.

description:
I haven't got much to say about this place.  It was pretty, and popular, but just kinda uninspiring.  

I don't often find myself in the tendernob, but I'll be keeping this place in mind as a good place to stop in.  It's got that facade of class - I'm crazy about those ceilings and found the lounge seating appealing, but the mirrors with the white owl designed looked like they were poached from Old Navy display.  Reasonable drinks, youngish crowd.  Nothing too crazy going on in here.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
When I first started working for Yelp I came up to SF to spend the week and get some training. While gallivanting around town and trying to suck this fair city dry of its alcoholic contents, I passed this little dive bar and was mighty curious. But as luck would have it, Rye was call my name and we went there instead. The next time I returned to SF, I really wanted to try this corner little dive, but sadly, due to Bobby's passing it was no mas and I never got to try the little hoo hoo hoo house that peaked my fancy. Bummer.

A couple years later and a few nights ago, I was out on the town showing a few new CMs the drinking ropes and a friend suggested the Owl Tree. I thought, "Surely You Jest! Not Theeeee Owl Tree?!?! I Thought It was Closed!?!" (Actually I don't think in Shakespeare, but blame my fingers, that's what came out) Sure enough, it was the same Owl Tree location, but sadly, nowhere near as cool or divey as the original.

With that said, however, the place is nice, but because I have an incredible sense of loyalty toward shit holes and dive bars with old men sipping bourbon, this place didn't really make me happy in the toes or the pants. Instead, it's just a nice, glam little bar in the middle of the Tenderloin and I think tourists would find it Neat-O and a welcome surprise in an otherwise sketch neighborhood. 

Will I be going back, sure, it's a bar, they serve alcohol so what's not to like. But as far as a top fave, nah, just kinda wanna remember the memory of the old place.
author: Stephy S.

description:
Solid.
But I miss the old Owl Tree. Owls in every corner, old men, and chex mix. This newer version has no soul.The bartender expertly made our rounds, and the specialty cocktails include top shelf libations made with fresh fruit. But just, hmmmm. . . . phony, like that girl from high school who shows up at the reunion with a new face. When I want slick and pretty I'll stroll a few blocks over to Ambassador. . .
author: Kia B.

description:
From Eater SF:
3) Things you would not have seen before (the C. Bobby constituent may want to shield their eyes): a bottle of St. Germaine next to a bottle of absinthe, "Reserved" placards on leather booths, lots of bartender cleavage, HD TV, a little velvet rope outside.

Velvet Rope?!  Reserved placards!!
Travesty.



And yes, I'm totally going anyway.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Great cozy bar/lounge in the heart of sf. Was with my cousin here few months ago.!
author: Vivek P.

description: A really old joint and when something is old and it's survived, it's cool.  Good drinks, good staff.  Stop in for a drink sometime before or after dinner.  It's cassic.
author: A.J. A.

description:
Jack and Ginger.  A basket of Owl Tree brand party mix and a wet-nap.  C Bobby and the tiny dog who serves as doorman.  Some things just go together.  

In-sti-f'ing-tution.
author: L W.

description:
I like the Owl Tree. I like it a lot. We used to hit it often when my buddy lived on Pine (pun totally intended).

The sign itself is one of my favorite of all time, all places. To this day, I can't drive down Post St. without saying, "Oh, look, the widdle owl can't stay up wiff da big owls. Him too widdle."

Actually, that was our usual slurring as we breezed this lovely respite at last call. Us too firsty.
author: Andy R.

description:
This is all you need to know about the "new" owl tree.

1) Bring your gangsta cash roll and just give it to the bartender, cause if you want more than 5 drinks in a night for you and your company, you will be dropping either $100, or your ring finger in a napkin, your choice.   

2) It is owned by the same architectural wizards that own Harry's on Fillmore, in which you need a hum-v and a light saber to move around in when crowded.

3) Although the shoe box memorial to Bobby in the corner and bowl full of crunchy things is nice, it will never be the same. It looks and feels like an Ambassador light, both in clientle, decor, and price, and will probably become a meeting place for the Marina-nostra that are already heading to the neighborhood. 

We're sorry Bobby. Thanks for the memories.
author: Matt M.

description: Saturday night at 9:45pm. They keep it from getting packed. Mango mohito was delicious, an old fashion with Breaking and Entering was a lot of whiskey but drowned in normal ice so it got diluted really quickly. Very disappointing
author: Ojus P.

description: For anyone who fondly remembers the real Owl Tree--stay the hell away from this place. They really should have changed the name. It's nothing, absolutely nothing like the Owl Tree. I'd suggest naming it the "Douche-Tree." Flat-screen T.V.s? Drinks with Blueberries in them? Surely C. Bobby's spinning in his grave. He wouldn't serve half the people I see hanging out front. I'll never set foot in this place. And it's probably good. I don't like you, you don't like me, let's leave it at that. Such a shame the old Owl Tree died with Bobby. It USED to be the greatest bar in SF.
author: Jason G.

description:
what an awesome bar - we wandered in here last friday night and had such a great time!

i'll be back now that i know its such an awesome place. yummy drinks, swift service, awesome atmosphere.
author: laura f.

description:
In college I used to roll with some trust fund kids, one of whom lived right in the NobLoinSquare area (because, whatever, her parents owned the building) and I always meant to move there. I adore the neighborhood. 

So I've decided to move into the upstairs of the Owl Tree. I could not have picked more fantastic decor for my little apartment than burgundy shag carpets and roaring 20's dancing girls on the wallpaper. One of the many reasons why this bar is so fantastic is that boys have to use the bathroom downstairs, but girls get to ascend such a fabulous staircase to get to our special little upstairs powder room (you can tell Bobby keeps it clean and pretty because he's old school and we're ladies) that it could be an apartment all its own. My apartment. It makes you feel like a princess. It really does. 

Another thing to note about the Owl Tree: if you're going to be throwing back Ketel One like it ain't no thang (because call drinks are very reasonably priced) make sure you eat some dinner before you get to the bar. Because they will bring a neverending supply of snack mix (Gardetto's, I think, which is not vegan in case you were wondering) right to your table (which is surrounded by some *fabulous* vinyl chairs that I'm sure they stole from my grandparents' den in the 70's) and you will not be able to stop with the snack mix. And I can think of a hundred places I'd rather be than a tummy full of Ketel One and snack mix.
author: Megan W.

description:
I LOVE the Owl Tree.

Now, you Yelp Purists are saying the bar is starting to be overrun by "Slummin'" Marina Jocks who are Wannabe TenderNob Hipsters(SMJWTH).  I haven't been here in awhile, so while this may be true, I will NEVER take the owl tree off my list of favourite bars for three reasons.

1. The gin Gimlet is sensational.  Very classic.

2. Owls friggin rule.

3. When handing us the bowl of snack mix, the bartender realized the proportion of good snackies (read: mini sourdough bread chips) to boring snackies (peanuts and pretzel sticks, I'm looking at you) was tilting towards the boring side, he (I KID YOU NOT) takes it back to pour in more of the good stuff.  He did this WITHOUT US SAYING ANYTHING AT ALL -- not that we would have, that is.  

And THAT, kiddies, is called customer fucking service.

Thank you and good night!
author: Dianne d.

description:
Don't usually find myself in this area but was out having sushi with colleagues on a Tuesday night nearby.  We were looking for another drink and my buddy basically spun in a circle and pointed to the Owl Tree on the corner... none of us had heard of it before.

When you enter the ambiance is totally unexpected, it's much nicer than you would think, with comfortable leather sofas and dark wood paneling.  There are generous bowls of nicely salty party mix displayed around the bar and we even caught the very end of their cheese and cracker buffet.  

The bartender was very friendly and attentive and the music wasn't overpowering while being solidly eclectic... I think I remember hearing Gipsy Kings, Beach Boys, Def Leppard, and Prince all in a row.  Owl has a bit of the feel of a quiet marina lounge (is there such a thing?) displaced to become neighborhood bar in an area away from the popped-collar crowd.  

It seemed like a friendly crowd of people all blowing off a little steam.
author: David K.

description:
So Bobby is gone but the Owl Tree carries on. Here's the scorecard:

Things that are the same:
Salty Snacks
Wet Naps
Vegas-y furniture
A shitload of owls
Crotchety bartenders (although much younger)
Too small martini glasses
Too small bathrooms
Jukebox
Weird S&M wallpaper on the stairs
People bringing in food
People leaving their trash
Roller derby girls sneakily trying to smoke under the table
Undisclosed/Unknown hours
Groups standing on the corner totally pissed off that it's closed and now have to find another location for their birthday/happy hour/date. 
First-timers reactions

Things that have changed:
No Bobby
No Chester
No live bar internet feed

Same: 15        Changed: 3
With that score, it looks like we should still go to the Owl Tree!

4/5/07 Update:  Walked by this morning and windows were covered up with a sign that now says "Out of Busines". Stay tuned.
author: Lisa R.

description: Great little pub with happy hour on Tuesdays. Not sure if it is everyday or not, but worth the stop.
author: Scott M.

description:
Dammit.

(stupid busy life.  *kick*) this has been one of my favorite bars on the planet but I've been out of rotation for months.

That's it.  Imma go out and buy a 40 and drive to CBsOT and tip one.  

Sad times.
author: ChubbyBunny I.

description:
This is tragic.  Next month I'm heading to SF and was looking forward to a return trip C Bobby's.  My girlfriend used to live in San Francisco and this was the one place I knew about and she didn't.  I was really excited about taking her there.  I just read this morning that it's closed.

It's a great loss, both man and bar.  Here's to ya C Bobby!  Half way across the country we raise a Lone Star to you.
author: Kyle H.

description:
Update 3 (6/4/08): Oh, yeah. The Owl Tree is back. If it weren't for the chandeliers and the etching on the mirror, it would be a dive bar (sadly in need of more owls - I say we start donating them). The music is still great, the clientele all sang along (yay, I missed that), and the drinks are great (there's even one on the menu that's Bobby's Dry Martini). Awww

I'm glad to have my neighborhood bar back!

Update 2 (2/26/08): The sign is different! The old yellow one is pictured above, but the new one is red with black lettering and a black owl. Does this mean there's going to be a new Owl Tree bar?

Update: There's a new liquor license in the window! We'll see what happens next - whether Owl Tree itself is reopening (however damaged) or if a new place is taking over the location. This is all I know officially - http://www.sfweekly.com/2007-05-30/news/empty-nest/

My review to make this appropriate: I love this place. It's everything a neighborhood bar should be. Great drinks, comfy seats, great people-watching and some hilarious interactions among patrons. Plus as many owls as you can shake several sticks at. It closed and I am sad.
author: Shawna S.

description: I love the Owl Tree, and I always have.  When I used to live here and it was in its original incarnation, I adored the Owl Tree.  I appreciate the New Owner's homage, in decor and in the memorial in the back staircase,  to the dead past owner and even though it isn't the same, it is still fabulous.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
Classy place with a great vibe.

Come by after work or late night either way its a great place to lounge and drink
author: Ares I.

description:
Who let these mother f***ing owls in this mother f***ing bar? Seriously though, this place rocks. 

Bobby's Owl Tree oozes with character.  1000 (well maybe 200) owls of all sorts decorate this divey bar in the tendernob. Plastic Owls. Porcelain Owls. Glass Owls. Posters of Owls. Owl menus. I kid you not.

Service is top notch and old school. Where else do you get a basket of nuts/pretzels and a wet nap with your drink. A wet nap---now that's service. This is a must visit. Definitely one of the top 100 bizarre bars in America.
author: Dave S.

description:
I had been here before when it was the original owl tree..this version is strange--  honestly, I just don't get it. The cheesy/modern inside coupled with the old-school owl themed former self just doesn't work. The plasma screens with sports games showing are also out of place (this place does not seem like a place to watch a game...at all). They seem to be renovating a room upstairs- not sure what that will be. 

The bar is way too small to come with a group of friends, so not sure why people choose this as their watering hole. Perhaps it's the memories of what it used to be that bring people back.  Not me.
author: Sonia S.

description:
Hm, there's nothing really wrong with the new Owl Tree, but with the passing of Bobby, there went the Owls.  So really it's more the "Owl" tree in spirit rather than in reality. 

There is the funky tile mosaic owl which I do like on the exterior and the interior itself is quite nice and modern, but if you liked the old Owl Tree, it's quite the departure.

The service was good and they even had free appetizers so you can't complain about that, but this review is more in relation to the original spot.

I'm sure most people who come here who hadn't been to the Original incantation of the space will appreciate it as a standard bar but for those of us who loved the C Bobby version, it's definitely not the same...
author: Gene X.

description:
Unless you haven't realized it from reading the other reviews, this place is OWL THEMED.

One Owl, Two Owl,
Red Owl, Blue Owl.

I love bars with a little bit of weirdness! I also love that they serve cheap strong drinks here. The crowd is great. The bartenders are great. What's not to love? They even give you snack mix while you drink yourself into oblivian. It's close to downtown so you can go shopping and then stop by for a drink. Definitely a keeper.
author: Cindy P.

description:
I somehow missed the sfgate article from october about Bobbys passing. I guess i was out of town, but still. I cant believe i'll never get to go there again and watch him freak out on anyone. To be fair, sometimes he was super cordial to all who passed under the owled curtain. Luckily, Bobbys son is keeping the owl flag flying and the tree is open for biz. GO! The jukebox, ambiance, snacks and drinks are the best around.

update: apparently the son of bobby couldnt keep the owl flag flying for long, booWHOOOOO...somebody please buy this treasure and open it back up!
author: rachael s.

description:
Hi All, 
Well I have been out of town, on and off the last 2 years, with sick family in Miami! My name is Allyson (the blonde with the little boy Alex, now.... 23 - LOL) I was a  bartender there for Bobby (my Other Dad!!) and I think lasted the longest (for a woman LOL) I was there about 87 to early 90's anyway I have a lot of pic's not to many  of the later years!!! I am wanting to put together a slide show! I hope Chris & TJ didn't get rid of all the pictures as I know there was tons of them upstairs. Hoping Michael got a lot of those things. Nobody seems to know where TJ & Chris is (I have a good guess)!! So after all that, anyone have any pictures or know how to get a hold of Michael ..... Please let me know! I'll be checking this place from time to time!! My Heart Goes Out to Everyone! - Bobby was a very Good Man with a Big Heart (if you did your part!!) 
I'll Miss His Strength!
All My Love,
Allyson
author: Allyson K.

description:
~NOEL~ the hottie behind the counter, certainly was the highlight of the night!

This place is truly incredible! has been transformed to a local hang out spot right at the street corner block! 

About a year ago, this place was nothing but then a trash hole! And at one point, was even shut down! 

But, Since i was in town for business I decided to check out my old 'hood~ and fair enough~ i dropped by~

AND~ I can't get myself out of it!

First of all, the trouble wasn't my feet~
was m EYES! 

NOEL was breath-taking~ and it was the full compliment from both Gents and Babes in the bar that night~ 

anyways~ Its a great Bar~ great hemisphere~ electrifying !

Beer, Full Bar, Wine List~  you really OUTTA come on DOWN!
author: Andrew W.

description:
Disclaimer: I would like to give this place 3.5 stars, but you know, Yelp.

Anyway, I never got to go to the former incarnation of this place, despite always wanting to (I'm a bit of a Bohemian Club conspiracy nut).  I was happy to hear it had reopened but obviously it's been gentrified a bit in its second incarnation.  That's the bad.  The good is that even on a Saturday night, with the bar packed full of a fairly obnoxious touristy crowd, I was able to take my large group upstairs, which was virtually empty at 9pm, and remained so until nearly 11.  Feeling like you have your own VIP lounge is pretty rad!

Also, they had Hangar One vodkas, Hendricks' gin, and a bottle of the Mark West Pinot Noir open, all favorites of mine.  Yes, the drinks were pricey, but at least we were paying for good-quality liquor in them.  The cucumber gimlet was quite tasty and strong.

One major annoyance: an exasperated barback kept hassling us throughout the hour and a half we were there, chiding my friends for taking some of the cheese and salami that was downstairs up to our seats, and complaining that we had too many people (at the end we had 11 people).  I don't get it - we were being polite and tipping well, and it wasn't too crowded.
author: Sarah D.

description: This was a small casual bar good enough for a small group. I really enjoyed the ambiance. It's kind of dark but cozy.
author: Nhung T.

description:
nice little bar that hovers between dive and lounge. the downstairs always seem a bit more busy than upstairs, but that's probably because people want to get to their libations faster and without having to climb those tight windy stairs. personally, i like the upstairs part much better. less crowded, large comfy couches/chairs, good music, and a good vibe. the bartender (hey shawne!) is awesome. she's always friendly and attentive. :) 

all in all, i like owl tree. it's nice to go to an unpretentious place without a bunch of douchebags. but that's a personal preference, of course. :)
author: Sally T.

description:
2 star less for the full of attitude lady bartender with no personality and a bit of the divish vibe. I'm really not for the vibe. It's pretty nice actually, it's like between Irish pub and lounge. The selection of tequila and vodka was nice.

The decor looks like it's a bar for a old school steak house. It's cool though. Poleng crew took us here after Rye. I liked there alot better, and I don't think I will come back here.
author: Kokoro I.

description:
If you sit in the front corner to the left of the door, you are in exact position to be stared down by the white stuffed owl that hangs directly above the bar. He has (had) blue eyes and a really creepy expression...for an owl.
Things that make this place great (aside from all the owls)
1. An excellent Gin & Tonic. And by excellent I mean stiff as hell.
2. Chex Mix. Need I say more?
3. The Wetnaps that come with the Chex Mix. AMAZING! I think wetnaps should come with everything. Especially in this dirty, dirty town. Why do they only come with Crustacean type food? There are dirtier things than Crustaceans, am I right?
4. Chester the Dog. Cute dog. I like dogs in bars. There should be more of them.
5. The Bartenders wear white shirts with bowties, and they look pretty no nonsense. That's as it should be in a bar covered in owls.
author: Elissa D.

description:
Dive bar meets 70s lounge... And I fall in love.

As other reviewers have pointed out, this place looks exceptionally dingy from the outside. But as the saying goes, never judge a bar by its sordid cover: 

For a Thursday evening at 10pm-ish, it was surprisingly not overrun, though comfortably crowded, and we managed to snag a table. The two large televisions screening Dirty Harry were a treat (panoramic Clint Eastwood: YES!) and the Anchor Steam went down sweetly. Two restrooms -- one tucked next to the bar and the other upstairs (with cool light bulbs!). Dim lighting, comfortable and varied seating (old-school booths by the door), and intimate setting. 

Dayum. So simple and yet so right. 

I'll be back.
author: G. J.

description: This is a small lounge - just a handful of cozy, comfy booths in addition to bar seating and space upstairs for private parties.  I was here towards the end of the night during a bachelorette party but I clearly remember stiff drinks and a relaxed crowd that didn't seem to mind a group of screaming, laughing girls - some people even stopped by our booth to congratulate the bride-to-be and snap a photo with us.  Loved the vibe!
author: Evelyn C.

description: This place used to be a total Tenderloin style dump. Then they closed down for a long time, remodeled (probably needed) and is now kind of a lunge type place. They have jacked up the prices as well (10 bucks for a Manhattan, etc) But I usually get beer anyways.
author: Jim B.

description: I'm a fan of the Owl Tree for two reasons - they  have good Happy Hour prices and  free snacks. The snack spread is probably the best that I've seen in any bar. I'm talking cheese, crackers, meat & chex mix. What more can you ask for?
author: Krystal C.

description: Worst service at a bar by the male server, who sits down using an iPhone instead of assisting customers.  The female bartenders work hard, but unfortunately the one bartender who does not actually work causes an issue... The regulars are on the low side of the spectrum, but that isn't too unusual for this type of a bar. The one star goes to the bar backs and female bartenders that actually do work! Given the few nights a week one cannot receive decent service by someone in the service sector it is a no go.
author: Ginger M.

description: Fantastic bartender and comfortable atmosphere.  Drinks are super yummy at a totally reasonable price.  The door man is nice too!  My boyfriend really loves the mango mojito, but all the specialty drinks we tried were tasty.  If I lived in the area I am sure I'd be a regular.
author: Meg D.

description:
