I scoped this place out last night for the first time in about 3 years.  It hasn't changed much at all and that is a good thing.

Let's see.....

Aside from the fact that I had to climb a fairly good size hill to get here I have to say that this place is all class.  Not in the way that the Ritz is class but more in a 'old school SF' kind of way.  They bartenders here (C. Bobby as well) are dressed to the T and are friendly and firm.  While the drinks are pretty spendy the service and the feeling you get being treated like a customer and not just another scum bag drunk (ever go to the hip mission bars?) is worth the extra dollar.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Yay!  This place has finally opened!

The space is quite limited, but intimate (the owner whispered to me that the upstairs space will soon be available for dancing--- excellent news!)  The decor is too cute for Tendernob, which is actually a good thing, as anyone can love the dive price but not necessarily the dive interior.  In short, this place welcomes post fancy dinner/pre-club crowd in their shi shi attire, and us, a group of aimless Friday night rebels from the hood, in jeans and flip flops, looking to get drunk.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
A nice little bar to grab a few drinks after work (or after a long day of lazying around). The staff is friendly, the place is cozy, and the prices are decent. It can get crowded around happy hour and it's not the biggest place, so don't try rolling up with your 20 work buddies... but other than that, and considering other options in the Union Square area, I'll gladly pick Owl Tree over some tourist-infested pit.

I never knew the old Owl Tree, but this "new" one is fine by me.
author: Chris M.

description:
Not the "old" Owl Tree, 
A pleasant bar just the same,
Happy hour lunch meat.
author: Brian J.

description:
If I wanted to focus on the slightly pricey beers, I could do that.  The place is a little small and only one bartender can be tiresome if you aren't the person being talked to at the moment.  And yet, whether it was because I was on vacation or because they were playing the Kansas game when no one else was, I loved this little place.

The atmosphere is nice.  A little dark and classy.  Etched mirrors, nice LG HDTVs, comfortable seating.

It was a good mix of locals and tourists when we were there.  The drinks were properly strong, the music was good/eclectic when they switched it on... from Sinatra to 50 Cent to the Beatles.  

Happy hour is a $1 off of anything you order which was a nice bonus.  I also liked the simple Cheez-it brand snack mix they gave out for free.  It was nice to know it was prepackaged and not mingled with random people's germs.
author: Bryan M.

description: Owl tree has been kind of chill lately. It's a good 'after work' bar that's not super duper crowded. The drinks are pretty cheap and it's central enough that you can make it a stop before going to other neighborhoods.
author: Klevin D.

description: For an up and coming area this bar is making a big splash. Yes its basically the reopening of an old neighborhood staple, but its being reintroduced by the same guys who manage/own Harry's Bar off Fillmore St  and Bruno's over in the Mission. I plan on swinging by soon, but have been antcipating going there ever since they finished the owl mosaics along the walls outside the bar.
author: Charles L.

description:
Fun cosy place. Its a bit crowded downstairs, but they have some fun drinks on the menu. Not too many places with a dark and stormy. I saw it on the menu but were out of it when I got there... hmm. Had some dry cheese and some tasty meat slices. Cant beat free stuff. They could have used another bartender downstairs for a while. But its still a small place so usually 1 should be enough. 

I think this is a cool place to predrink with a date. Intimate, cosy, nice ambiance. Hey and its right down the street from the Cellar! Friday nights, best 80's night ever. 

Ill be back with a date, but not with a group of friends.
author: Roy L.

description:
I've tried for years to be describe the charm of this place, to little or no avail. One long, narrow wooden bar, dimly lit, frank or johnny on the juke and the owls (yes, they exist and there is no way to short the preponderance of them) staring at you while you're sipping your cocktail. Which will, most likely, be fantastic, if Bobby has anything to say about it. 

This place is decidedly old school -- the drinks are stiff, the scene intimate and laid back, the chex mix free and continuous. Coming here is a lesson in how people used to drink. 

One piece of advice: know what you want before you talk to Bobby. If there's one thing he can't stand, it's people wasting his time. That's one of his charms.
author: Geof M.

description:
While it's probably not fair to rate a place on opening night, I was fairly disappointed because I had such high hopes. 

Two points are mainly for the decor and booths because the drinks were ridiculously hit and miss and the crowd was fairly annoying. When I looked at the menu I was pleased to discover they had Fever Tree products, I was not pleased when not one but two bartenders attempted to make my gin with Fever Tree bitter lemon not with Bitter Lemon but with Ginger Ale, at least I was more observant the second time and able to stop before they actually made the drink. 

As for the opening night crowd, hopefully they won't be regulars because they were beyond annoying. A drunk girl and her much more sober partner literally danced into our table and spilled an entire beer on my boyfriend without so much as a sorry or an excuse me. 

One point added because the bar gave my boyfriend a replacement beer to make up for the one that he ended up wearing. 

I will try it out again because it's close.
author: Tara A.

description:
This is NOT a dive bar...and how dare it (or anybody) call it that, especially in a neighborhood filled with some of the best dives anywhere! It's way too fancy (updated/contemporary interior, lighting from fixtures that aren't Xmas lights, electronic music, etc.) and nobody in there is of the "dive bar" variety.

If you are into dives and live in the neighborhood, you don't need to be told where to go. But if you are visiting and want to hang at a real-deal SF dive with the local drunks, just march in any direction away from the Owl (or scan my reviews!).

But if you are looking for a place to drink in Lower Nob Hill that doesn't have a cover and is filled (literally; it's very small and fills up fast) with tourists that were sidetracked on their way to the Marina, then step right in to the O.T.
author: Derek R.

description: It's actually pretty classy here.  My friend had a birthday gathering in the upstairs lounge and if you get there early there will be no problems whatsoever with seating! It's a little small up there, though, so I could see it getting super packed on some nights and it will probably get hot fast... but crack a window and let the cool SF breeze come in and you'll be just fine.  Bartenders are real nice, their drinks are pretty good and didn't do too much damage to my bank account!
author: Mercy D.

description: I don't know what I was expecting, but that wasn't exactly it.  The Top 40 came as sort of a surprise to me, and the volume was a tiny bit on the loud side for the size and decor of the place (at least on the ground floor...never quite found the other portion people talk so much about).  And for $9, the Hendricks cucumber gimlet wasn't quite worth the price.  It's an interesting concept to marry dive and lounge, but I think I'd take 5th Floor over Owl Tree for my pricy cocktails around Union Square.
author: Jenn C.

description:
At least I made it to the old Owl Tree once or twice before it closed...

So we went in the other night in the spirit of the old joint, and hoping for a new bar even closer to our apartments. We are overeducated alcoholics that read books and hate you, so now you have some reference. First impressions - too much pleather, really bad music, and too many Union Square tourists speaking German. An their liquor bottles are set up with two top shelves - one vodka, one tequila. This was not looking good.

Whatever. We sat at the bar, each of us ordered a Woodford Manhattan. The bartender grabbed Maker's...umm...and she poured them with about a 3-count of Vermouth. The barback guy brings them over and says..."18." I asked him for clarification - these were $9 each. And they were the second-worst Manhattan I've ever had in SF (only the Asian girl at Hyde Out pours them worse). Painfully awful.

Nobody with soul walked through the door for the next half hour, they had a Blu-Ray dvd player running the original Ocean's 11 (because nothing shows off high-def like a film from 1960) and, except for "When the Leveee Breaks," the music stayed atrocious. Also they have one toilet. So there will always be some uncomfortable Indian family in there helping each other poop, or whatever the hell all those Indians were doing in there for ten minutes.

We pounded our sticky-sweet Manhattans and went to Whiskeys, where you trade a bit of class, of which I have precious little as it is, for proper drinking.

It's a shame. My friend and I should have bought the damn Owl Tree and done it right.
author: That Was A Good Drum Break ..

description:
What a great bar!

Hadn't been here since the remodel, but enjoyed drinks with friends in the upstairs lounge/bar area. Very nicely done, with little attitude, good drinks, and hip crowd.
author: David G.

description:
Beautiful Bar but nothing special. It was a week night tho that I went...so I expect to go back and try it out in a weekend to see what type of people really come out and play in this TL bar. 

I was glad to be with my friend Terika went I went, because it probably would have been a total snore fest without her...
Did strike up a conversation with one girl which was nice - until she tried to pass her creepy friend's email address on me?! So I could add him to facebook? Weirdo. (but not a reflection on the bar)

Anyway...over all...the bar was beautiful, my white wine was less than $8. I'll probably will go back to see the bar on a different night, but won't rush the visit since it was a so so visit.

Ps: my friend did say she thinks the bartender looks just like Antonio Sabato Junior. I kinda agree.

Pss: No jukebox - so minus one star for not being able to pick my own bar tunes.
author: Katy A.

description: A happy hour favorite. This place is cozy, the drinks are tasty (blood orange margaritas - yum!) and the staff is pretty friendly.
author: Joe C.

description:
After hearing about this bar from my bf and his bar-loving friends, I finally got to check it out for myself! Before the renovation, the Owl Tree definitely had a higher weenie to ladies ratio- no longer! While the interior still has an old feel, the crowd's much more balanced now. Inside is very cozy and they even serve you snackies (which my empty stomach GREATLY appreciated!). You can help yourself to some salami, crackers and cheese and some nice bartender even came around to give each table a small bowl of Chex Mix! 
I'm a fruity disposition type of girl so I was drawn to their blackberry martini and pomegranate martini. I asked the bartender which one she recommended. She suggested the blackberry because it's made from fresh fruit- mMMmMMmmm she was right... it was gooood and I could barely taste the alcohol. 
I'm bound to return. It's in a great location, it's filled with a good crowd, the drinks are tasty and the customer service is great! Go Owl Tree!
author: Amanda W.

description:
To be fair, the ambiance deserves four (and a half?) stars. 
Maybe I just haven't been around long enough to see one, but I've never heard of a vodka gimlet. Had to ask that it be made with gin. Not a huge deal really, but given that it is *that* part of town and even middle shelf drinks run upwards of 9-a-pop, I tend to expect a razor sharp bar tender.
author: Alex B.

description: Just went there for happy hour and it was perfect. Was meeting up with a friend's parents visiting from Scotland. It's divey, classy, comfortable, laid back and elegant all at once. Comfortable seating area, friendly staff (even after our Scottish friend left a $1 tip on 4 drinks - it was almost like she looked at him and kindly silently said, It's okay, you're Scottish and we know your friends will come back). And we will definitely be going back for a drink after work.
author: Katie M.

description:
This is an SF institution and by that I mean you feel like you're the only one not swallowing the pills while everyone else is drinking the koolaid.  Bobby's a real hoot. Awww Johnny yer killin' yerself. "I'm here 'till Tuesday." Okay, enough w/ the funny stuff. Bobby will serve you right. Jack and cokes or whatever your poison. He's been there forever...and so have many others. Good ol' school place to start the night out right. 

2 duckets for Bobby, 1 ducket for the drinks, 1 ducket for the owl.
author: Johnny C.

description:
I've only been here a couple times early in the week and on a Sunday.  I unfortunately never made it to the original and my thoughts go out to Bobby.  

That said.  I like this spot.  It was low key, the decor is slick but relaxed.  The bartenders are pretty attentive.  Drinks were solid.  The one Tuesday I stopped by it was relatively quiet but by 11:30 it was jam packed.  Apparently many of service folks (e.g., bartenders, chefs, restaurant folks) pack the place early in the week nights.  I'd definitely keep going back.
author: Rafael s.

description: This is my first review for a hetero bar, (I'm sure there's terminology that's hipper, but it's the first word that came to mind), never fear, yours truly , still fearlessly walks the rainbow.  Seriously though, I've been here twice, both for get-togethers with fellow co-workers and I've really like the vibe here.  When there not playing some sports related program, they'll play a movie filmed here in San Francisco, always an interesting addition to the ambience of the bar.
author: Carlos C.

description: Had the feel of an olde-time "supper club" bar.  Dark.  Small.  Our group gathered after dinner in the back at a large booth.  Prices seemed fair.  I liked it!
author: Jennifer S.

description: As most Yelpers noted, props to the Happy Hour with its fine spread of cheese, crackers and meat and, most importantly, serving utensils. Snacks are always welcome but these are Tier 2 munchies baby (Tier 1 is hors d'oeuvres like tuna tartare, mini empandas or pigs in blanket of course). Renovated fairly recently, the classic leather booths, mirrored walls and red carpeting do provide a pretty enticing place to meet up with friends. Angela the bartender was attentive and proper. This bar joins my short list of bars to hang at!
author: Kim K.

description: Fresh blackberry martini, "the laughing policemen" on tv, sat downstairs at the bar and had a lovely time.
author: Sarah S.

description: Yelp Drinks definitely pointed me and my friends in the right direction when we were looking for tasty, stiff ones (that's what she said) and a place where we could all meet. Owl Tree is mos def a spot the homies can relax and enjoy happy hour. It felt like I was riding in a fancy train car, with all the lovely mini chandelier sconces and wood paneling. Comfy lounge seating, complimentary cheese and crackers, and amiable service--enough to be a competitive establishment in a city of awesomeness. Might be a little on the cozy side if you have a bigger group, but rubbing elbows is all a part of the fun. Will be back the next time I visit the city.
author: Dee L.

description:
DO NOT PISS BOBBY OFF!  I got sloppy in this joint and forgot to always respect my elders, especially when they run the greatest dive bar in SF which coincidently is in the crap neighborhood of downtown, and got my drink tossed and my ass excommunicated from what I thought was safe territory.  This place is easily a 5, but I dont want to give it away to easy grazers.  This place is a world of its own and everything about it is just plain great: the guard dog, the mix, the drinks, the total slave bar keeps under B's ever watchful eyes.  If your kid is a trouble maker, forget boot camp.  Send him to be a bar back and server at The Owl Tree.  Its almost painful to watch when he is reallly pissed.  The hours are a pain in the ass too in the winter but keep trying, this place is a jem and I hope Bobby lives and works to 150.

UPDATE: The world has lost another wonder.  RIP Bobby and The Owl Tree.
author: Porfirio R.

description:
Not the greatest bar  so it doesn't get the vaunted fifth star but it was a nice little spot. Friendly staff, clean environment, decent drinks and decent prices.  Doesn't try to rip me off on beer.

I actually prefer the dive bars to the fancy schmancy bars but this place is cool.  Relatively laid back.  You can go in with some friends, grab some drinks, chat.  Music isn't blasting so talking doesn't involve yelling at each other at the top of your lungs.  

Nice place.  Generally well recommended.  Go, drink and be merry...
author: Aron L.

description: My favorite bar in the City. How can you not love a place that serves $3 Blue Moons everyday and offers a free plate of crackers, cheese and salami to boot? Dim lighting creates a cool vibe and the bartenders are some of the nicest folks in town. The music selection is the best and is all over the place in a good way; which is why this place rocks. We're talking Ice Cube to BeeGees;Stone Temple Pilots to Manilow. Voytec makes a great martini and remembers your name several months later. My kinda place.
author: Rick W.

description: Neighborhood pub meets ritzy touristy SF district.
author: Sushi S.

description:
Bobby serves up a stiff drink.  I'm not sure my gin & ginger had any ginger at all.

Love the owls, love the comfy chairs (I think my grandma has something similar), and love the quirky cute bartenders.

EDIT:  I was at Bobby's last night  and Bobby told me my drink (whiskey sour) sounded "yummy" and had the bartender make him one too.  ...Swoon...
author: Katie S.

description: I walked up to the owl tree early on a fri night and the bouncer put his hand up in my face to tell me to hold on. Really?  All I did was peacefully walk up to the door. I'm not trying to run past you or anything. Tell me you're full at the moment or handle it any other way. Dont be a jerk. I will never ever go back to this bar!
author: Lynn M.

description:
I love this place, and I love living right by it. I think the bar is called the Owl Tree, because Bobby is a hoot! I have seen him take an order and refuse to make it because it he doesn't want to. He has insulted people, kicked people out and just plain ignored them. What's not to love. The Owl is back open on a regular schedule and I couldn't be happier.

UPDATE: July 2008

Well, a lot has changed now that Bobby has passed away and the drug addicted son moved into the bar. It's now been sold, and reopened. Thank goodness! It is a great neighborhood bar, much like our "extended living room" in the hood. There is a great crowd everynight of locales and tourists. Check it out, and I guarantee something crazy will end up happening to make your night just a little bit better :-)
author: Jason D.

description:
The only word to describe my experience at the Owl Tree is...ODD.

Walked in with my friend (we're both young asian women), as soon as we stepped foot into the door an old rich guy in the corner with a girl on his lap yelled to the bartender to make us his 'famous' shot.  Consisting of red bull and some tangerine thing.  I can't even remember.  It was good and all.  Then we walked over to the other end where there were ODDLY serving salami, cheese, and crackers.  Two more guys felt the need to approach us.  Of course it was one of their birthdays, OF COURSE, and we had to take birthday shots with them.  Didn't bother them at all that we were in our early twenties and they were hitting 50.  We proceeded to leave when one of them ran after us to hand us a bowl of mixed nuts.  Hmmmm...
author: Tammy L.

description:
It had a reasonable choice of drinks.
It was relatively quiet.
It was relatively dark.
The decor was not obnoxious.
The price of a shot of Oban was obnoxious.
It's got an odd, but amusing choice of theme.

They played "Let's talk about Sex", AND "Baby Got Back" within 1 hour
of each other, which was an interesting choice of sound track to a 
1st date.
author: Max R.

description: Nice atmosphere: quiet, chill. Very limited seating.
author: Catherine T.

description:
This place is great!  Free Chex mix at the bar and I'm an instant fan, but I would avoid the meat and cheese plater, ya never know where all those hands have been!  Drinks are mixed well and priced just about right.

I really like the cozy upstairs bar, cash only, so if you are paying by card make sure you get your drinks downstairs before.  Grab a seat and relax.  Fun times await.
author: Ethan K.

description: Cool bar with cool owl style. Love all the owls on the mirrors, and the staff is super friendly. I wouldn't say this is the coolest bar I've been too, but I have enjoyed my time here! Not digging the ridiculously long lines for the bathroom- I think there was only one stall? But the upstairs area is cool-hot and sweaty- but cool for private parties.
author: Sonya D.

description:
The owner just bought us drinks!  No idea why!  Yay!

Also, the bar back Lupe is amazing!

This is awesome!

Yay!
author: Dee B.

description: Small, but cozy place to chill with close friends. Friendly mixed crowd and bartender makes good drinks. Try this place if you want to stop somewhere to grab a quick drink or two before your next sf destination.
author: Samantha C.

description: I went here last night after a thwarted attempt to get into the Ambassador.  Being unwilling to wait in a huge line on a Tuesday night in the pouring rain, we wandered around until we came across the Owl Tree, and I'm glad we did!  It had a great feel to it-- comfortable seating, a good atmosphere, and reasonably priced drinks.  I'll definitely be back on a different night when the upstairs area is open!
author: Erin B.

description: I was a huge fan of the old Owl Tree as I'm sure a lot of folks were and was curious how the new Owl Tree was.  I have to say that it looks pretty nice and the bartenders are friendly but it doesn't compare to the original.  It doesn't help that I was stuck next to a local who wouldn't stop chatting my ear off when I wanted to have a conversation with my girlfriend.  The drinks were rather expensive too.  The best part of the new Owl Tree was the memorial to Bobby which you'll see when you head to the bathroom.
author: Blake B.

description:
There were no seats at The Hidden Vine, so my friend and I decided to try this place across the street.  It was exactly what I was looking for on this particularly glum Thursday evening: a dark, quiet bar in which I could drown my sorrows in a tiny but potent whisky sour.  When I finally looked around and noticed the kooky owl theme, it cheered me up a bit.  Thank you, nice bartender, for bringing over the free round of drinks!

5/07 - Huh, it's closed.  But what will become of the owls???
author: DD B.

description:
Talk about a gem in the rough. Now granted my friends and I had just been irritated (ahem, rejected) by the bouncers at Slide, but I found Owl Tree to be a delightful surprise. My first impression was not good. Only one bartender (a hot woman with boobs that were too big for her body...not that I'm complaining) who seemed to be serving too many customers by herself. But within a couple minutes she came over to me and served me the best mojito I'd ever had - perfect muddle of mint, sugar and rum!

I suppose the experience was made by my friends but the mood was chill, noise was fairly loud, and this place was comfortable. Drinks weren't too expensive either (not all that cheap - $17 for two mojitos). The bartender was even nice enough to serve me first for a second round.

I'd come back again.
author: Aaron F.

description: I am a huge fan of owls, beautiful creatures.  This bar has tiled walls outside of the bar designed in the shape of owls, etched glass owls inside, the remains of the original owl decorations encased in a glass box from original bar before the owner passed away and they redesigned the inside.  This bar is on the classier edge of the scope of bars, not a dive.  Therefore, a bit pricier fancy drinks.  I had the pomegranite martini which was delicious and the leche pineapple martini, delicious.  Great jukebox and the music that I can recall playing was Eminem & Michael Jackson.   They had a small screen television showing sports. The bartender and other employees were really nice. There is an upstairs bar but it was not open when we were there.
author: Dayna C.

description:
I wanted to like this newly renovated dive bar for my friend who was eager to take me there since she has fond memories of the old Owl Tree.  However, the whole place was way too Union Square meets Powell Street for me (too small, too expensive, and too close to all the crazy tourist activity).
We tried the pomegranate martini and the straight up martini- neither was very big for the price and  both were only "eh" for flavor- and how can you mess up a regular martini?
author: Holly B.

description: great happy hour, free meat and cheese plates, free pretzels, affordable fresh-squeezed cocktails, nice bartenders, nice crowd, what more do you need?
author: Mark A.

description: I'm just sad that the current owners kept the name of the Owl Tree. It is a bastardization of C. Bobby's Owl Tree which was my favorite bar downtown for many years. From what I can tell, nothing survives from the old Owl Tree. The current owners vandalized the space by replacing the noir-y  1940 black vitrolite storefront with those cheap tiles and stripped the interior to make it appeal to pop collared, valet-parked, douchey/fratty Marina transplants, who appear to be the main clientele at the present. This bar was one of my only beach heads north of Market Street and now it's gone. I wish I had gone in with my friends to buy it when C. Bobby died a few years back. We didn't. We're lame.
author: Christopher V.

description:
SEE IMPORTANT UPDATE BELOW**

C Bobby's - 
scene: 
c bobby face down on the bar. enter hipster girl with backless dress. 

Cbobby: "Put yer shirt on - this ain't no tittybar"
Hipstergirl: "Whatever"
Cbobby to young buck bartender: "Get her the f*&^$ outta here."

End scene

Cbobby's: Naked lady wall paper, a pink ladies room, and owls.

BY THE WAY
I have a hypothesis about the Owl theme - I used to assist a Bohemian Club member.  You know: "Weaving Spiders Come Not Here", crazy powerful worldrunners, the annual July encampment  up in the Russian River, all the drunken pagan crap and no ladies allowed while they figure out who should go to war and who should buy what country but HERE's the relevance - 

Their mascot is a GIANT OWL.  

Their building is the brick building located cattycorner from the Owl Tree.  If you walk up the Taylor side and peer inside the entrance on a night the Movers and Shakers are hanging out together, you will see the GIANT OWL that watches over all it's Bohemian Club children.  

And my husband says there is no connection.

***IMPORTANT UPDATE
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2006/10/12/BAG61LNO301.DTL
C Bobby has passed away :(
A funeral will be held today, October 12th, 2006, at 7:30 p.m. at Halsted N. Gray-Carew and English mortuary, 1123 Sutter St., San Francisco. 
God Bless Bobby.
author: Robyn C.

description:
If you are scared of owls or do not enjoy large beady eyes staring at you, I would not go to the Owl Tree Bar.  For the rest of you that don't mind Owls, this is a great old-school bar in the middle of many new modern bars.  It is a place you might find in Fargo or Kalispell.

OOOO!  OOOO!
author: Lulu B.

description:
I do love the Owl Tree.  The eclectic selection of music on the jukebox would be discordant anywhere but here.  The clientele seem always to be friendly, not in your face friendly, but laid back and easy, the whole scene - unpretentious.  

I see reviews claiming it's now been "discovered" by the city and the subsequent prognostications of doom and degeneration at the hands and feet of the trendy masses.  It does not seem to have changed yet and I sincerely hope it will not.  I have a feeling that between Bobby's rumored ferocity and the decor somewhere between my Grandmother's curio cabinet and old gritty San Francisco swank that the trendy masses will be deterred at the door.
author: E R.

description:
Owl, Owl, wherefore art thou owl?  The answer: On every single painting, etching, or photograph suspended on the walls.  Very cute bar  with a nice, rosy-hued 'n cozy ambiance.  On the evening my friends (and no, I didn't pay them to accompany me) and I set foot in the place and secured a corner table, the waiter approached us to take our order and returned with a delectable basket of Gardetto's snack mix.  We munched, sipped, and chatted over the blues music being played.  An hour later, we sauntered out, relaxed and content.

Addendum:  If you are looking to "scope out some hotties", then this is definitely not the place for you.  Well, not unless the qualities which you seek  include acute noctural vision and head rotations of up to 270 degrees in either direction...
author: Momo R.

description: Enjoyed happy hour here this past week after a long day of being funemployed..I appreciate places with $3 drafts, although I wish they had more choices. It's got a great vibe, and I hope to check it out more often.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I really wanted to give this place a four-star rating. And I believe after I visit the Owl Tree again it will grow its fourth star accolade.

After an evening full of wine and more wine, the Owl Tree was the perfect transition back to my typically beer-filled life. Service was quick and the bar wasn't too packed. And the people watching was exceptional.

Also exceptional was the jukebox. At one point Fiddler On the Roof started playing, in true tribute to the randomness of this little dive.

I predict C Bobby's bar will become a regular on my beer circuit. And I hope to one day add an owl to the mix.
author: Josie Z.

description:
WHAT HAPPENED?!

My friend showed me this place sometime in 2005.  It was a Thursday night.  The bar was full, a couple of the tables were taken, that was about it.  It was a calm but fun atmosphere (hard not to be fun when there's hundreds of owls scowling at you).  The bartenders were attentive, fun and mixed a good drink.  They gave you Chex Mix and little wet naps when you were about halfway through your first drink.  I went a few more times after that, and it was pretty much the same.  Once the owner was there with his crabby little dog.  He yelled at the bartenders and they were good-humored about it.  He thought I was sitting at a table with 3 women whose large boobies were hanging out all over the place and gave me the round I was buying free of charge.  He was annoyed when I went to sit down with my boyfriend and our male friend.  We still got great service, good drinks  and Chex Mix, though.

And then I went a couple weeks ago.  The drinks had grown in price and shrunk in size by at least half.  The place had many more people in it, almost packed, and only ONE bartender.  The bartender didn't seem much interested in anyone who wasn't sitting at the bar (we weren't), but was somewhat friendly when he finally got around to us.  No Chex Mix, it didn't look like anyone got any, though I saw it sitting there.  The crowd was mostly middle-aged yuppies who looked annoyed.  I'm not the kind of person that really goes to bars/clubs that are filled with young and "beautiful," so I don't mind the middle-aged yuppies, just the drink prices that tend to come with them.

So...I might try again on a weeknight, but I don't know.  I think people are more aware of its existence than they were when I first went and it's turning into a normal FiDi overpriced tourist trap with runoff from Ruby Skye (ew).  Too bad, the decor & the jukebox are fantastic.
author: Ljótur H.

description:
I do miss the old Owl Tree Bar, but I'm glad that they've at least kept the name (even if there's nothing owl about it).  The renovation is good.  I like the mosaic outside and the interior is cozy enough.  I've only been once and early--my preferred time to imbibe.  

I did have a chain-store sense and the bar-back confirmed it when she mentioned she was temping from another of the owner's establishments.  My drinks were fine.  Nothing to write home about, but not bad at all.  

The memorable exchange for me was watching a patron micromanage the creation of his drink.  "No, more freshly squeezed lemon."  "A bit more Cointreau."  The patron's face was familiar, but I couldn't place it for a time until he thanked the bartender for the drink.  It was a great bartender from Tosca's!  I wasn't sure what to be more embarrassed about--one bartender manhandling another or the willingness of the bartender to be so cowed.  

As (a few) other reviewers have noted, there's nothing really wrong with the new Owl bar, but it's terribly vanilla right now.  I hope with a bit of time it will build more character.
author: QuodE D.

description: Love this quirky dive.  Great for late night cocktails.   Great staff too.
author: Alex L.

description: **FYI** there IS a minimum for the Swanky Upstairs Lounge and it's ONE THOUSAND DOLLARS. Apparently it's non-negotioable, it doesn't matter how long you are there and how many guests you have.
author: Eva T.

description: Well it is a scene now. They've done nice things with the place, but... not the place to duck in for an intimate nightcap.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
When I loudly announced how much I was in love with this place and how I was going to steal a menu as a souvenir, the bartender took that as an invitation to take away all the menus from ours and all surrounding tables.

Unfortunately, this place was discovered and now it's overcrowded with the kind of people who would normally never set foot in the Tenderloin, except, of course, for the Hip Quirky New Bar.  Kinda sucks, you certainly can't get a table anymore.  Go back to the Mission and take your emo haircuts and white belts with you!
author: Frankie D.

description:
R.I.Temporaneous

Liked the exterior lighted sign with the Owl.

Interior totally creeped me out with all those nocternal eyes...tooo many voyeuristic feathered eyeballs..without a shred of intelligent conversation to keep it fascinating.

maybe go in with a bookworm to catch the attention of the wise h-owl.
author: miriam b.

description:
The new Owl Tree gets only one star for destroying the old cool alkie dive bar that I loved. 

Okay, okay, I'll give them a second star for using Fever Tree mixers and having high quality booze. I fully admit that if you didn't go to the original, you won't know what you're missing and will probably love the New Owl Tree.
author: Rochelle M.

description: This is a great spot to grab a drink upstairs. The couch was open - which is a huge plus for me!  I have to say in my older age...now that I've hit 30...I have come to treasure a bar with a place to sit.  Especially when I wear uncomfortable shoes! So being able to chill in the back on the couch upstairs, with a not-so-crowded bar close by...good stuff.
author: Lauren F.

description:
"The greatest bar in the universe."

Bobby & Chester - the coolest. 
I always think of owls on a Friday, just now in the wrong place. 

Happy Trails C. Bobby.
author: Jen S.

description: You know when a certain bar is a personal bar when the bartender doesn't have to ask you what you want to drink...AND...the bouncer knows your name and greets you with a hug.  My drink is always just right and the bouncer is always looking out for me!!! The bar-back always refills my snack bowl...and I just feel like I am home.  This has become one of my favorite spots these days....and I highly recommend it.
author: N F.

description:
I guess people really like the old style, but I can only tell you about the remodel.  It's has a very cozy feel with dark woods, nice bar, with booths along the edge.

There seems to be an upstairs, but never ventured up.  It looked scary.  There's only one bathroom that everyone has to share.  Friday happy hour included free crackers, cheese, and sliced cold cut meats.

The bartenders were friendly and the drinks were reasonably priced.  $4.50 for Blue Moon and 8 for mixed drinks.  Both were good.

It's a good place to hang with friends and catch up.  If you don't like em just watch the two flat panel televisions.
author: Po L.

description: Super cool, chill atmosphere. Great vibe, decent music playing with a nice mix for all. If you're looking for a gem of a "dive bar" this takes the cake. You won't regret going in. Four stars only b/c the female barkeep seemed annoyed when I ordered my drinks since I am not a local. Everyone else was cool.
author: Tyler A.

description: Great bar, awesome jukebox! Popped in around 10pm on a Friday night based on the proximity to my hotel and the Yelp reviews. As usual, Yelp never steers me wrong. It got a little loud toward the back of the bar, but since the music is so fun, it's hard to get annoyed. I could wax far more poetic about my evening at Owl Tree, but let's just say we stayed 'til just about last call, and I'm rarely in a bar for that long. Ah, yeah. Good times were had by all.
author: Avitania B.

description: It was a better idea for Hollywood to make "The Dukes of Hazard" into a feature film than to butcher the memory of this once great bar with its new incarnation.
author: Christopher K.

description: Hoot hoot don't pollute...my ears with your horrible music selection, whoever is in charge of music needs a new job! Drinks are ok, crowd on the weekend is so/so - douchey.
author: Rachael Z.

description: I love this bar! It's definitely a new favorite in SF.  It's small and quaint and can be filled with tourists as it's on the corner of Post and either Mason or Taylor.  The atmosphere is dark and loungy, and they have the cutest little mini-chandeliers on the ceiling.  Apparently, it's called Owl Tree because they used to have a bunch of stuffed owls inside the bar.  The music is pretty quality too, as they play anything and everything from 80s to new indie rock.  Only issue is that it's a bit pricey.  $9 for a glass of semi-decent wine?
author: Jenny W.

description: I almost got ripped off here, but twas ok. I called them on the bad math and they admitted fault right away, yay for good people. Boozes Flowed and I went home /w a special someone. Its a good drunk test methinks, if you forget math you've most likely had enough. Heavy handed drinks help happy too. mel brooks movies make any bar better, and this place was rocking them.
author: Jab U.

description:
I am reviewing this bar out of spite. It sits at the end of the block I live on, a reincarnation of the former Owl Tree, though the two bars share nothing in common except location and an owl-centric decor. The New Owl Tree is a gentrified version of an actual bar, complete with extravagant fixtures, over-priced drinks and stripper-like bartenders with big fake tits. 

As I was saying, spite, only because I walked by everyday salivating with anticipation for my new neighborhood bar to open up just 30 feet from my front door. Instead of a neighborhood bar I get a Union Square leech bar that easily prices itself out of my after-work happy-hour options. 

Congratulations, proprietors of the New Owl Tree, you've done your part to expedite my neighborhood's transformation into a shiny pile of unoriginal, uninspiring shit. Cheers.
author: Phil D.

description:
C Bobby is unfortunately deceased as the original owner, his sons have picked up the torch at this superb little bar that makes you feel relaxed & at home. It has an East Coast feel with an excellent, old-school jukebox. Do not miss an opportunity to pass this ternder-nob gem up as it sometimes has odd hours of being open.

I may get criticized as a Marina Type in the TL because I trend towards the preppy side however you should know if you want to be a snob:

1) I live in SOMA
2) I was born & raised in SF. Most of the 'hipsters' are transplants.

Anyway Owl Tree is in my top 5 favorite bars up there with The Bucanneer and Tosca.
author: M P.

description: Amazing!  This place is my new favorite hang out.  It has two floors and is small, but very cozy and inviting.  I loved the decor, vibe and music...upbeat but not over the top or too loud.
author: Megan H.

description: Loved this little bar, the decor is very subtle and dark which I love, and the bartenders are knowledgable and quick with the drinks...plus they have bar snacks (it's a good thing as martha stewart would say)
author: Andrew M.

description: Since I've lived in the neighborhood for a while, I remember Bobby's Owl Tree. The reincarnation is very nice, very comfortable, etc. I honestly think if this glorified dive bar is going to stick around through the economic downturn, they need to start pouring heavier or reduce the prices since $9 for a mediocre cocktail is too much. My friend and I had only a slight buzz on, and that was after spending $60 on fruity cocktails. But you know, the tourists love it and they seem to think nothing at dropping too much doe on drinks.
author: L v.

description: I am sincerely torn about this, as part of me SO appreciates the obviously respectful nod to our (drunken) past. However ... given the former Owl Tree was an institution that simply cannot be replicated, perhaps a new name may have better served our collective closure. When Esquire singled out the old Owl as the 'Best Dive Bar in San Francisco' a couple of years ago, I remember how genuinely pissed-off Bobby (the owner) was over the attention, so in a way, this new incarnation would ironically be his worst nightmare come true. Regardless, it's here and quite snazzy now, and does make a great addition to the neighborhood. And for the record -- should I ever own my own home, I plan to chip away that awesome abstract-mosaic out front to use for a fabulous kitchen back-splash. Kudos.
author: Gregor G.

description: Screw the Owl Tree. The other day, Sunday, when it rained non-stop my boyfriend and I scurried over to the Owl Tree while waiting for Coco Bang, that Korean joint across the street, to open, and it was 4:30pm when Owl Tree's opening time is supposedly 4pm we huddled against the door with puppy dog eyes and pantomiming that we wanted to get in, and the bartender looked at us and mouthed "five more minutes" and held up five fingers. SCREW YOU. It's pouring rain outside and you can't let us in 5 minutes "early" (25 minutes late) to just take a seat while you finish setting up the bar to warm up and dry off???!!! Burn in hell dude!
author: Laura M.

description: Nice classy decor, great ambiance, young crowd and great drinks.
author: Ben C.

description:
i love bobby, i love his owl obsession/collection, i love his little socially awkward dog, chester, and i fucking love this place.  you shall know me by the sound of hall and oates that dominates while i am there.  also, fantastic free crunchies/pretzels snack mix! 

Update: ATTENTION VEGANS: delicious snack mix is not vegan...dammit!  sucks because it is SO DELICIOUS!  Also, that shit ain't chex mix, it's gardettos.  bobby is all class, people.  ain't no chex mix up in this piece.  shit.

actually, i take it all back.  don't come here.  go to swig on geary instead!  WAY more fun!

ANOTHER UPDATE: Bobby is so fucking grumpy...he kicked a woman out for not speaking good english the other night!  What an old codger!  ALWAYS go to the bar knowing what you want to order and speak clearly!  Also, know when Bobby puts on his scarf to go home that he is looking for love.  Are you?

YET ANOTHER UPDATE:

RIP Bobby.
author: Laura B.

description: I went here on a Saturday during happy hour. It wasn't crowded so we easily got a table. The drinks were really good and cheap. I really liked the atmosphere of the place. The crowd was older but it may be different at night or during the week. However, I will definitely come back!
author: Ashley B.

description: Nice small cozy bar. I expected it to be a dive bar (I think it used to be) but seating was ample and my friends and I were able to sit back and relax
author: Eric A.

description:
woo-woo has a hoot of a happy hour?  why owl tree of course.  

they have non-chintzy free food (cheese, salami, stale crackers) and a swanky upstairs option for large parties in the evening, which i recommend for a birthday celebration.
author: jane d.

description: This is where I had my first taste of Anchor Steam!  This is a lounge type atmosphere--on the smaller side, and it's nice enough (if you can get a seat).  I managed to snag a booth with the two others I was with.  It was close to my hostel, so that's why we went here.  Probably wouldn't go here if I were a local.  Everything was A-OK because of the Anchor Steam though.
author: Claire S.

description: It's like being in a movie - the sleaze & grittiness of the Nobby Loin (tm Ms. Lula Mae), the so kitchy it kind of makes you sick decor (owls, owls, and more owls) & an incredibly cranky old legendary bartender. And to top it off, the Chex mix just keeps on coming.  It almost hurts me to write this review. A mythical place.
author: Maria D.

description: When I think of the bars in the Tenderknob, I usually picture a gritty dive bar with cheap prices, stiff drinks, and a rough crowd (both inside and outside of the bar). Yet, when I stepped into the newly remodeled Owl Tree, I had to take a second and check the sign. The plush decor, unique mirror designs, and free appetizers (I know, who does that anymore!) presented a welcoming atmosphere. The drink prices weren't inflated, there wasn't a cover, and instead of the having "the house DJ that's trying to make it big" in the corner, they had a good old fashioned juke box. Up until now, my favorite bar in the area was Royale, but I might have to rethink things...
author: Michael H.

description:
all i had to do was peek in the door and realize that the wonderful old owl tree was completely gone.

why'd they keep the name the same?  why didn't they just make it a new bar?  it's not the same at all.
author: Kate W.

description: So sad that Bobby passed and the Owl is closed.  So long old friend.  Please please please let someone open it back up with the same feel.
author: Amme P.

description: Kattya hearts The Owl Tree!
author: Kattya B.

description:
Good drinks and free snack mix and cheese/cracker tray.
I had the cucumber gimlet and it was pretty good and strong! My first gimlet EVER... I had to look up the word.
It was a cozy atmosphere with a really random assortment of music playing.
author: Corey H.

description: Do you want stuffed owls and owl pictures on the walls, Gardetto's snack mix and wet naps served tableside? Go here.
author: Rick H.

description:
What was once a real bar with true character has been sold and rendered into another unremarkable human grease-trap.  It's a travesty that they still call it the Owl Tree.  I'd guess that if everyone who rated the bar before the previous owner Bobby died were to update their ratings, this place would be hovering around two stars.

[EDIT:  :(   Rest in Peace, Bobby.  :(  ]

I like this place.  Going there and ordering a drink from Bobby gives me a thrill that I imagine is not dissimilar from the thrill one gets from walking into a cage with a trained lion.  It is unlikely that the lion will rend your body the moment you turn your back, but it is a very real possibility.  Yes, the owl collection is dazzling, but see my review of the evil Bohemian Club across the street, note their insignia--the sinister Owl--and then go to Bobby's Owl Tree Bar and look just above and to the left of Bobby's cash register.  Do you see what I see?  Now I don't know if Bobby is a Bohemian Club member or even a sympathizer, or simply a small business owner trying to increase his revenue; I haven't had the nerve to ask.  All I know is, be careful what you order in Bobby's bar.  I've seen this lion snap at many an ignorant drinker for ordering something stupid like a "Manhattan on the rocks," or Jagermeister.  As for myself, I never, ever go wrong with a super dry martini, and I always exit the Owl Tree the same way I enter it--facing the bar, with my wits about me.
author: Mynameisdavid M.

description: This place is sweeeeet. A coworker took me to this bar, and I was quite pleased. The drinks were good and at a reasonable cost. The atmosphere is perfect for gabbing with friends, or that significant other. And you have this retro feeling when you walk in. The owl decor might creep you out, but after awhile, you think it pretty awesome and wonder how they have this huge owl collection.
author: Beth W.

description: Overpriced drinks at a revamped dive bar...And the bartender was not very nice...He was to cool for skool for some odd reason?  Total turn off...But I did end up meeting some fab people their that whisked me away to the Mango Absolute party at The Clift in the Spanish Suite...so I am happy I went their since I met cool people...but I wont be running back anytime soon...
author: Michele K.

description: Walk by this place everyday on the way to work since moving to the city a few months ago and noticed last night that it was open for business! Called the peeps and sat in the back booth and reveled in the tacky-swank, kitschy decor and odd mix of music. Kind of reminds me of the Fireside Lounge at the Peppermill in Reno minus the fireside... Think I'll definitely be coming back for more!
author: Donna V.

description: I think this place is beautiful. Really really pretty. It just screams regular spot for an upscale but down to earth neighbor. It seems to attract a mix of locals and business travelers, and it just feels classy, even though it's a bit of a dive.
author: Monika M.

description: UPDATE - The Owl Tree is currently being refurbished & looks like it will reopen soon.  I'm afraid it won't be a dive bar anymore but we'll see.  I just hope they put all of the dusty owl chotchkes back.
author: Erin S.

description: Came here for a late night drink, just as they were doing final call around 1:20 am on Friday night. The bartender made a nice amaretto sour with vodka in it. I would probably come here again after going to the Hidden Vine across the street.
author: Antara B.

description: This place is quickly becoming my go-to bar!  Drinks are consistently great, nice (and quick!) service, and always some room to sit down and quiet enough to sit and chat.  We actually stopped in on New Year's Eve after dinner and a show and cover was only $10 which included the first drink!  What a deal!  Even on the biggest party night of the year we were able to get a seat, which was awesome.  Looking forward to seeing more of this place in the 2009!
author: Jaimie M.

description: Blown away by the design detail from the outside to the inside. Very cool chill bar. Heard much about it and checked it out Sat night with friends.  Cool, friendly bartenders and great selection of booze. All of us loved it!  Knew Bobby (the man who owned the place before his death) and this is really a nice tribute to him. Very cool.  My friend made me cross the street to check out the outside walls. What a trip!!! Right on!
author: herb w.

description:
It is dark and cozy inside. The bar seems to be lined with regulars. So I made a few new friends while saddling up to the bar. The drinks are yummy and happy hour special is always a PLUS as you get a discount. For happy hour, they offer a platter of crackers, cheese and salami. It is a nice touch, but I don't recommend eating it as it not very tasty. However, the pub mix they offer with your drink is very YUMMY.

There are sits away from the bar which is great for large groups. Music selection is awesome and at the right level so you can hold a conversation without having to shout or strain to hear each other.
author: Jenn K.

description: My Mom is an owl freakazoid, so this place was immediately home to me.  Add to that, older men playing bar dice (the hint of Dad in the air) and I could sit here all day.  I swear I saw Beck in there one day!  I wish someone had played bar dice with me, but the owls kept me occupied for hours.
author: A W.

description:
the charm of this odd place, and its gnarly and bitchy proprieter, is ruined by the abundance of pink collared shirts and chestnut st. refugees that now patronize it.

to learn about the creepy, uberpowerful and all out scary as hell secret society "the bohemian club" that give the owl tree its name (the club's mascot is an owl), visit http://www.aidd.org/societies/bohclub.htm


eeeeekkkkk.
author: calamity d.

description: Another one star for having some dickhead verbally abuse me over my listing. And another thing -- the drinks are way overpriced now.
author: Darren M.

description:
It is with sadness to announce the passing of Mr. Robert "C Bobby" Cook.
There will be an obituary in the San Francisco Chronicle on Tuesday, October 10th and Funeral Services will be as follows:
VISITATION:
Wednesday, October 11th  / 12 Noon - 8pm
Thursday, October 12th / after 9am - 7:30pm
FUNERAL SERVICE
Thursday, October 12th / 7:30pm

All Services will be held at:
HALSTED N. GRAY - CAREW & ENGLISH
1123 Sutter Street (between Polk & Larkin)
(415) 673 3000
author: graham R.

description: Went here last night for drinks after a wedding and it was great. Just what we were looking for - cool little spot, and they were really helpful with getting a table for all of us. I'd definitely go back and could see this being a regular spot if we lived in the neighborhood.
author: Sarah R.

description: To all those who patroned here: I feel slightly dishonest writing something other than a review (seeing that I only came by here a handful of times. I remember the kooky owl decor and not much else) but I want you to know someone may have given Bobby an unintentional (but still fitting) send off. YouTube "I Left My Heart In San Francisco". One of the montage videos has (among all sorts of baseball, touristy type and nature shots) a perfect still of The Owl Tree sign lit up, open for business. It's the only picture in the whole montage that didn't look like it came from a postcard. My heart goes out to you folks for losing such a treasured neighborhood spot.
author: Veronica G.

description:
relatively close to work.

average prices.

decent bathroom.

small and dark.

LOVE.
author: Angela H.

description: From the outside it looks like a dive bar, and that's the mood we were in to contrast a lovely dinner at le colonial.  But once we walked in, we immediately noticed there is nothing divey about the place.  But it wasn't disappointing, the place has a very intimate  feel to it anyway, still nice and dark, and the bartender was friendly, always a plus.  Not overly loud, so you can hear yourself think and talk, which is always welcome.
author: Marina F.

description: Back in business and lookin GOOD. The remodel is respectful of the joint's history, plus the new mural (mosaic?) outside. Drinks went up some, but not obscenely. All the stuff i liked before (Gardetto's, dark wood, banquets) but in a sleek new package.
author: Todd B.

description: Great atmosphere for a weeknight (wednesday). The drinks weren't too pricey, the crowd was a-ok, and the staff was friendly. Good for just chillin with friends (nothing too crazy). The atmosphere upstairs vs. downstairs = two completely different worlds.
author: linda t.

description: like your crazy aunt's basement -- knotty pine walls, strong drinks, johnny cash, copious owls.  Owl Tree uber alles.
author: John M.

description: I think it is kinda divey. It's quite small and the drinks are standard but cheap. Hooray for cheap booze. Although the part of the night spent here is a bit grey, I enjoyed the intimate atmosphere.
author: Laura D.

description: I had some very good times here. First wandered in with my old friend Suzi about 3 years ago and have had a fondness for The Owl Tree ever since Bobby gave me a bowl full of pretzels and other assorted snacks. He was cool. That bar was really cool. I had an Owl Tree revival a few months ago when I started coming back more often after work. Took the great Jess(ica) here on the night she revealed she was leaving town for greener pastures up north. It was a fitting place to say goodbye and I'll always think fondly of the days and nights up in the tree. Stay classy, Owl Tree. I know you will...
author: Benji T.

description: Now, full disclosure, I was so drunk by the time I sloshed into this bar that I don't remember much of anything.  I do remember that the sign outside is really cute.  I am taking off one star because I think a creepy dude hit on me, yechh.
author: Amy M.

description: Good place, drinks are cheap for downtown, crowd wasn't annoying which is difficult to find in a downtown City bar. Bartenders are attentive, ...and gorgeous, which doesn't hurt anything.  Minus one star for the complete and utter lack of ventilation which makes it 1000 degrees in the bar. Other than that was a nice night... drank 3 beers and felt like I'd had a ton more, which is good for those of us on a budget.
author: Mckay W.

description: At one time in my life I spent 4 nights a week at the Owl Tree.  I was prepared not to like the place when I walked in. I was wrong, sure its not the old Owl Tree but Bobby is dead, it could never be the old Owl Tree without Bobby. "Get the fuck out of my Bar!" He was priceless.  The wet naps and bowls of mix are gone. The furniture is changed but it remarkably a similar feeling room.  There's a great shrine to Bobby on the stairs leading to Bobby's old office and the ladies room.  I was disappointed there was no urinal filled with ice and powdered hand soap.  I think Bobby would approve of the joint.
author: all seeing E.

description: You all forgot the best thing and I will cry if the Owl Tree re-opens and does away with the mack daddy Chex Mix.
author: patrick g.

description: I like this place.  The people seem different every time I've gone.  It can fill up fast and I like to sit when I go to a bar if I'm wearing heels.  It's dark, mellow, the music is fun and the drinks are good.  I like coming here after eating at Ryoko.
author: Carmen S.

description: This place was supposed to be cool a long time ago, when Bobby was the owner and the bar was called "Bobby's Owl Tree."  But I think T. Pain or someone took it over cuz now it's like "I'm in da clurb" at the Owl Tree.  The architecture is really beautiful inside, and the windows are great and blah blah but really it's the Marina that comes in here to shit in my drink and yell at the TV.  And the music is like autotune shit hop and music my mom would dance to to feel groovy (see light rock for less talk).  One star for pretty light fixtures and cool ceilings and one star for the upstairs sex lounge.  Ok, whatever, the little room upstairs with a bunch of cushion things to sit on and white curtains and little lights.
author: Liza W.

description: Put on your t-strap shoes, grease up your pompadour, grab your clutch before leaving the apartment, roll a pack of cigarettes in your white t-shirt and head on down to the Owl Tree. This bar has been around since before prohibition, and has been under its current name and motif for more than several decades. A real class act. The interior is packed with owl paraphrenalia under low lighting. Small intimate space, and friendly bartenders. All drinks include a wet-nap and bowl of chex mix.
author: Netty L.

description: One of my top favorites in the Tendernob--  it just OOZES tendernob. Swanky yet kinda sleazy. 1950s jukebox, overstuffed vinyl armchairs, chex mix, cigar in the dark den atmosphere. Oh yes, and stiff drinks from the bartender who can be friendly or grumpy, and his? little dog that wanders around. Poor dog and his delicate ears. They just started having a bouncer for some ridiculous reason. And the owls?  lots and lots of owls, if it weren't so great I'd assume someone went insane
author: Amy D.

description: If you like dive bars and extensive collections of kitschy artifacts, you'll love the Owl Tree.  This place is sweet.
author: Andrew E.

description: Bobby is dead, no kidding, he died a few weeks ago. The world's best bar will never be the same. There will NEVER be another C. Bobby, nor another Owl Tree. Whatever vultures buy this joint will likely put in a large TV screen and add crap to the jukebox. I will never drink again.
author: Skinkton Z.

description: came here for the USA vs ENG world cup match after the disaster that was the phoenix irish bar, 2 samsung HDTV's and much more relax atmosphere, and noelle slinging drinks.
author: Pickle R.

description: How have I never even heard of this bar before?  This is the quintissential great neighborhood bar.  Fun crowd, great vibe, and a bunch of freakin weird owls all over the place staring at you.  Owl clocks, velvety owls, oil painted owls, you name it.  More owls than you can count.  Yah, it's a little weird, but I like it.
author: Erica G.

description: My new favorite spot. It's a little creepy with all of the owl eyes looking at you, but they have a pretty awesome jukebox. Paul Simon AND Whitney Houston?! It wasn't too crowded late on Thursday night, and the bartenders were pleasant to our large group. Glad to discover that it's right on my block. You probably shouldn't take the owl-shaped menus, but they do make cool little souvenirs.
author: Dave K.

description: If this place ever finishes their remodling, do yourself a favor and stop in for a dink. Dont piss off Bobby cuz youll find yourself on the street with the rest of the riff-raff. Owls and a decent jukebox add to the flavor of a good martini.
author: Albert C.

description: A very good straight up bar. Cool, clean, friendly. Have been here for sporting events, drinks before a movie, and entertaining family and friends and I am always pleased with my experience.
author: Gabriel M.

description:
Yet another classic San Francisco neighborhood bar scrubbed of character and history--save its stolen name and a glass-encased shrine in back. 

Overjoyed to hear it had reopened--a plunging heart once I entered to find the space sleekified and stocked end to end with yupsters swilling overpriced cocktails. Not the type of deja vu I was anticipating or wanting. But I guess another upscaled bar is just what this town needs. One star for at least evoking happier memories.

By the way, does anyone remember the old Blue Lamp on Geary? Cool bar which met a similar fate.
author: ron w.

description: We went in after my friends' A.C.T play. Had a good time, had somewhat of a Balboa Cafe feel to it, yet catered to a bit more mature audience perhaps...? I'm not sure, I'd have to go there again, but good first impression.
author: Baris B.

description: More owl paraphernalia  than you can shake a stick at + snack mix + wet-naps + bartenders with ties = happiness
author: Brett L.

description: This is definitely one of the greatest spots in town.  If you are looking to kick your night off right or end it in proper fashion, this is the spot to do it.  From the dark decor to the well stocked jukebox, this place isn't missing a thing.  No need to slow pace the party mix, it keeps coming.
author: Brendan R.

description:
the owl tree has no relation to hooters :(

but the jukebox has hall & oates and neil diamond \:D/
author: James L.

description: The Owl Party Mix rules.  Having owls peering at you from every angle is actually quite comforting with a cold one in your hand.  This place is a hoot.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Great bar.  The bartender annually contended for grouchiest in SF.  His dog would have biten you.  If it didn't, its fleas would have.  If they did not, you can be assured the drinks would, which were stiff and cheap, and if you are an attractive guy, could have been free if the bartender liked the look of you.  Sad to hear he's gone.  C Bobby's is still worth it nonetheless.
author: Aaron F.

description: I really am sad about the news. What a special little place this is, the Owl Tree. Is it the snack mix? The lovingly created drink menus? The jukebox which housed the very fabulous "Calypso Is LIke So" featuring none other than Robert Mitchum? Or, the Owls in all of their glory? No, it was, shall forever be entangled with the memory of Dear C. Bobby. Was he in fact grumpy? Nope. He just wasn't all customer service fake hoochy-koo all over the place. He was a real person, and you had to show yourself as such. We'll miss you, C. Bobby.
author: Isabella R.

description:
yay the owl tree is open. i didn't know that the roof dropped and just thought it had bizarre hours. it's fixed.

it's not a dive, it's not snotty. the owner and bartenders are chatty. dark wood interior, orange candles, owl decorations everywhere. it's not too big so go early with a large group or grab the back table if on a date. just be careful of the chex-mix. it makes your breath stinky.
author: Jason M.

description: Quite possibly the coolest dive I've ever seen. We'll miss you Bobby! I hope God can fix a decent drink.
author: Keith R.

description: To celebrate my 25th birthday my friends took me out for dinner and drinks after work last night. After dinner at Indonesia we walked over to Owl Tree. We had seen the bar on other trips to the city but had never gone in. I LOVE owls. If I see something with an owl on it, I want it. Going to Owl Tree on my birthday was a perfect way to make the night special. Owl Tree is on a corner and from the outside you can see a mosaic of an owl and another cute owl on the sign above the door. The bar was full but didn't feel crowded. There is seating all along the bar and also a little lounge area with short tables. There are TVs for watching games and an upstairs room for private parties. We sat at the lounge area and felt nice and cozy. It was a nice escape from the cold. I ordered the pomegranate martini. This drink is pretty and festive with a bright red color. It was chilled just right and went down smooth. I'm not sure about all of the ingredients but it was sweet (but not too sweet) and had a hint of lemon. I also tried the Irish Cider, which was delicious. This is such a cool hang out spot and the patrons all seemed nice as well as the bar staff. The prices for the drinks were average. They serve wine and beer as well.
author: Daisy S.

description: I like owls. I like owl tree on weeknights, but on weekends it's too crowded with men puffed-up on their own san francisco-ness. on wednesdays and thursdays, the clientele is good looking and mostly straight enough that i twice met nice men. Nice Men - an oxymoron for many a bar  - are available here, and they buy your drinks (which are surprisingly affordable anyway). Even Anthony the bouncer and the awesome bartenders are nice. Alert, alert. It's, like, pleasant.
author: Angela O.

description: I hate birds, but love owls, and I love the Owl Tree (which for some reason I always want to call Blue Owl, will someone explain why I do this?). My friend and I went on a short bar crawl through the Loin, which is quickly becoming one of my favorite hoods to hang in-hey there are some cool bars in the Loin. Our last stop was Blue Owl, I mean Owl Tree. We each had the Greyhound with fresh squeezed grapefruit juice, delish. My friend and I both agreed that they had the best music of the night playing on the juke box. The only bad thing was the annoying people filling the bar, obviously after their work Christmas party (lucky bastards still got one). Hopefully the clientele is not normally as douchey because I want to go back.
author: Sarah M.

description: I came here on a Thursday night with some co-workers, and to my surprise, I actually enjoyed the place alot!!  Its not too far from my work, so I saw what the old bar looked like, and THANK GOD,they re-did it.  The old bar looked like a hole in the wall (I apologize to those who loved it before, and not so much now).  Can't hate on the free cheese and salami; that helped keep my buzz down.  I liked how they only served Priv (yeah, get rid of the cheap sh*t!!), when I asked for Hennessy.  The lounge chairs don't look all that clean, but who cares when you're drunk and having good conversation.  I'm definitely looking forward to going again.
author: Gail L.

description:
Judging by other reviews, we must have just been there on an off night.

We arrived just as the bar emptied out (theatre shows starting), and were able to get drinks really quickly. we decided to sit upstairs, and the angry waiter guy refused to let one of our crowd up because the drink (a beer) had been purchased downstairs. So, once the beer was imbibed, we headed upstairs, and lo and behold, they have te same beer at the same price upstairs!

We grabbed a free table, and started to relax, taking in a pretty friendly atmosphere. The music was so-so (Regulators? really?), but was low enough that we could continue giving each other shit without yelling.

Then, out of nowhere, the same angry waiter dude slams down a reserved" sign on our table. So I ask if we are being asked to leave, and his reply is: "Not if you're ordering more drinks" WTF???

Needless to say, we didn't order more drinks, and are unlikely to do so again.
author: Ben C.

description: Very neat little place, the furnishings are well kept and comfortable, they have a good foreign beer selection, the barkeep is friendly and attentive.  It's a good place to bring a girl because it is pretty quiet and comfortable and very neat and interesting to look at.
author: Cassio P.

description: Once a dive bar gets discovered, the charm is lost. Still a favorite to visit when in the area. Seems brighter than before and the dark optical discoveries of owls were haunting instead of what is now a gimmick. No worries, still a good place to strike up a conversation and have a mini-martini. A bit pricey for the size of the cocktails, stick with shots, wine or beer.
author: James T.

description: Ungodly expensive, but, attitude-laden, crusty old bartender Bobby makes it worth it. Perhaps because I'm a masochist, I enjoy the Owl Tree. I like the website because it makes my brain hurt, so much going on to take in at once. They have a live webcam tho, which could be fun if you are a creep and like to watch from afar.
author: Colleen B.

description: I miss the way it used to be, when there would be empty seats at the bar on a Saturday night, Bobby yelling at people, the little dog tottering around, the webcam, the stale Gardetto's mix. Now it's full of cool people, the service has improved, the pretzels are crispy, and it just doesn't feel right. At least they haven't changed the cd's in the jukebox. My favorite owl is the big white one in the nook all the way in the back. Bobby, RIP.
author: Josh K.

description: hmm, lots of owls, stiff drinks, good snacks and relaxed atmosphere. I wouldn't call this bar a place to pick up girls but they serve good drinks and have snacks. Nice if you are in the neighborhood, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go here.
author: Russ C.

description: "I love this place! I was supposed to be meeting friends at the Redwood Room, but I was not feeling the stuffy crowd in line. Walked up the street to find a gem! Stiff drinks, a fabulous jutebox and a cynical old bar tender, perfect combination! My friend and I have been searching for the perfect owl to add to his collection!
author: Lisa K.

description: Wouldn't it be fun if all the owls in this bar came alive at 1AM when it closed, flew around, hooted and stared at themselves on the web cam pecking away at the Giardetto's Chex Mix?  Every owl in here (wooden, Tiffany, macrame, stuffed, metal, etc. etc.) has its own life story, at least in my head.  I love this cozy little place--a curmudgeonly bartender, delicious snackies, well-made drinks and Sinatra tunes on the jukebox.  What more could you ask for?
author: Vivien W.

description: Gotta love a place that has it's own obsession. I mean, macrame, painted, stuffed, drawn, weaved owls...everywhere. And you gotta love a place that's kind of low key, just hip enough, and still about a good stiff drink. A fave.
author: Pierre K.

description:
Is a "dive bar" allowed to have a Web site?  Especially a site as snazzy as C Bobby's Owl Tree?  (And who the heck is this C Bobby character?  I fully get the owl part of the equation.)

Regardless, I can't say I hate this dive, and I can't say I like it.  It's apathy inducing. I can say that the last time I was here, the service was shockingly slow (understaffing seemed to be the problem); fortunately, counting owl paraphernalia kept me occupied while I waited.
author: Hannah J.

description: Because this bar is really close to my home, I really, really want to like it more than I do.  There is just nothing special about it.  The tile outside is really cool.  The booths inside are comfy.  Its not that its a bad place...its just it doesn't offer anything better than the next place.  The old movies being played on big screen TVs is kind of weird given the place appears to be going for a more classy look (decor).  The music is also confusing; its all over the place.  I do like the bar snacks.  The bathroom is very clean and nicely decorated.  The actual bar is very small and can get crowded and seatless very fast/easily.
author: Rise G.

description: u like ur bar dark? u like ur fellow drunks sassy? and um, u like owls? this is where u need to perch. i advise getting up on the bar stool mid-day with the regulars and hoot like an owl. by nightfall, the trendy crowd comes in and u'll be juiced up to flirt. whatever u do, if u enter in the day, don't leave til' nightfall. u'll feel like a vampire. it truly is as dark as a coffin in there.
author: S. G.

description: nothing compares to the old owl tree, but the new one isn't too shabby.  the new face is a bit swankier, and drinks are on the steeper price -- albeit poured with a heavy hand -- but the bar is cozy and is a great place to tuck into on those cold san francisco nights.  free bar snacks to munch on.  and i have to agree with some of the other reviews, one of the bartenders does resemble anthony sabato jr.
author: Sheri N.

description: love the look of this place, but the drink menu is fairly small and I was with a large group and not everyone was happy with that mainly the beer selection is weak.
author: Jennifer D.

description: One of a kind. Always guaranteed entertainment, whether it's from the half-in-the-bag bartender or the crocked up clientele. Plus, you gotta love any place that's got tons of Hall and Oates and Tom Jones on the jukebox.
author: Andrew L.

description: RIP Bobby. You gave me some special memories.
author: derek b.

description: C. Bobby would spin in his pine hollow if he knew what had been done to his corner bar.  This space is just reactionary - it lacks any kind of soul.  The mosaic was the first tip-off while construction was finishing, but after stepping inside for a few moments tonight I know what a field mouse might sense, swallowed, inside the belly of an owl: darkness and despair.
author: John H.

description: My favorite bar for reasons incomprehensible to most people I take here.  If you've ever spent as many drunken nights at Le Tigre in Madison as I have, you'd understand my deep affinity for the Owl Tree.  The owls, the dog, C. Bobby's crabbiness, the jukebox, the dark old broke-ass furniture.  The whole bit.
author: sunny d.

description: So sad to see this place go, was in my top three favorite bars in the city.  RIP Owl Tree.
author: Excitable R.

description: If you have a phobia of owls, I wouldn't recommend going here, but otherwise go for the decent drinks, divey atmosphere, and nutty characters.
author: John B.

description: One of the many hidden jewels in San Francisco, I really enjoyed my night at the Owl Tree. This is a cool two-story lounge with bars and seating both upstairs and downstairs. Unlike some bars, which try to minimize seating and pack the patrons in like sardines, the Owl Tree strikes that nice balance of being a trendy lounge, where you are actually encourage to kick back, sit down and have a nice conversation with your friends. Big Thumbs up.
author: Colin B.

description:
When I first moved to SF in early 1980's, I stayed at the Will Rodgers Residence Hotel, just across the street from the Owl Tree. It was my favourite bar in SF. Moved away 20 years ago and just came back to SF for a few days. Last night  I walked down to the Owl Tree and saw it closed with interior being gutted.  I feel DEVASTATED- I spent many an evening at the Owl Tree- I especially loved the way Bobby would answer the phone- "Bobby's Owl Tree, Bobby speaking"!

RIP Bobby, and thanks for the memories!!

Lily
author: Lily W.

description: i really liked this place! i found it randomly when wandering from the 2 bus stop to the 38. kind of pricey, certainly not going to become an every day place, but the drinks are of high quality and the ambiance is nice without being too stuffy. the bartenders and bouncer were all very nice and they entertained me and my drunk friend. delicious dirty martinis! i would definitely come here for a special occasion drink or to show visiting friends a classy san francisco bar.
author: Rachael S.

description: Average spot. Nice atmosphere. Pretty slow night though. Drinks werent as stiff but same price. Might check it out again to see if its any better.
author: Jameson B.

description: u like ur bar dark? u like ur fellow drunks sassy? and um, u like owls? this is where u need to perch. i advise getting up on the bar stool mid-day with the regulars and hoot like an owl. by nightfall, the trendy crowd comes in and u'll be juiced up to flirt. whatever u do, if u enter in the day, don't leave til' nightfall. u'll feel like a vampire. it truly is as dark as a coffin in there.
author: ray c.

description: loooove places like this~add this to your stop overs in snob hill....good crowd with various tunes playin on the ipod....if u cant find a seat on the 1st floor~take the upstairs route/more loungy with couches wit another bar..the drawing of the owl in front is a trip after a couple of gin/tonics
author: elmer d.

description: what a great place.  my new favorite at the moment.  the place is dark and mellow.  you can hold a conversation without shouting and the accommodations are cozy.  we spent most of the night upstairs and it has a very intimate feeling.  there are windows bordering the room but they are curtained so light is let in but privacy remains.  the bar tender shawne was an absolute sweetheart too.
author: Ryan H.

description: I stopped by with a friend who was visiting because I hadn't been to the Owl Tree since the new ownership and all of the changes.  Although I miss the old Owl Tree, the current one looks great/chic and the staff is super friendly.  From the bouncer to the waitstaff to the bartender, all were very cool and pleasant.  I hate going to bars where everyone's a downer that works there and this was the opposite.  It was upbeat and lot's of young professional men there ladies!
author: K V.

description: it's just my personal taste of course, but i love bars like this so much more than places like swig or rye. it has a warm personality and typically the people inside are there to relax, have a good time with their friends, and look at the owls. there are snack mix baskets that magically refill themselves before you even notice that they are empty and very comfortable chairs. did i mention the owls? in addition, the drinks are absolutely solid. the owl tree is just a real place with real people and every kind of fake owl you can imagine.
author: eric g.

description: Had drinks with my coworkers this weekend and I had a blast. It looks small outside but its a nice place to kick it friends. The drinks were good too. Even though they had my favorite beer the Blue Moon, I tried their Mango Mohito and it was great. The bartenders are really friendly especially their bouncer at the door. I would like to go back their and bring more of my friends to check it out.
author: Matt B.

description: so sad this place is closed!! the owl tree was a little gem. very swanky.  plus the bartender gave you your own individual basket of pretzels and wet naps. c'mon now. who could refuse that?
author: Joanna M.

description: This was my favorite bar ever.  I weep now that it has passed along with Bobby.  Those free snacky things were the greatest.  They had Johnny Cash and Waylon Jennings in the jukebox waaaaaaay before it became hip to dig them.  They were country when country wasn't cool.
author: gretchen d.

description: Yay! I'm a fan... it's a great location for us! It's casual and has that great lounge feeling. BUT!!!!! The pours are terrible! Go ahead and charge the big $$$ for your city cocktails but at least be a little more generous especially on a simple scotch rocks! We are locals... come on!
author: Bren E.

description: You called it Chrissie b. They've ruined it. It's enough to make him roll over in his grave. Rest in Peace Bobby!
author: chris g.

description: this place is cute. the decor is super classy, my shit doesn't stink when i drink in this bar. i like it when they open up the upstairs which is usually never... they should start doing that more often. the drinks are pretty expensive [at least the ones on the menu] but the bartender with the russian accent and huge muscles makes them strong so it balances out pretty good. overall i like this place, it's intimate and cute.
author: Amy S.

description: the owl tree is good times. you gotta love the owls in all their glory. and the snack mix is a nice little treat. i would watching out for the bloody mary though unless you like drinking a-1 steak sauce. and i think this place has a lot of class. i sort of resent that it's called a dive bar. it's quirky fun with a dependable bartender serving up liquid magic.
author: joseph j.
